output: Thank you, Mr. President. I greatly welcome the approach outlined in the White Paper, which seeks to identify the root causes of malnutrition and obesity, and the resulting diseases.
Unfortunately, in European food policy, we are falling into a very one-sided approach, whether we are discussing nutrient profiles, food labeling, or, in some cases, the White Paper.
We are, in effect, attempting to resolve the problems we have in Europe through product policy.
And I believe that it is a fundamentally flawed political approach to assume that there are good and bad foods.

Many change requests demonstrate this.
That does not exist.
There are only good and bad, or alternatively, balanced and unbalanced diets.
That should be our approach.
The causes of inadequate nutrition are multifaceted.

To rectify this by attempting to guide consumers through product labeling or even resorting to advertising bans or regulations, or by implementing different value-added tax rates, will not lead us to the objective.

I believe that everything we do here – and I don't want to anticipate the debate on the labelling regulation – should be framed under the heading: what can we do to motivate consumers to reflect on their eating habits?
In my view, a traffic-light labeling system that suggests I am now facing a good or bad product is more an instrument of disempowerment than an instrument of education and enlightenment.
Therefore, I desire a balanced approach here and the recognition that we will not be advanced by the path of product policy alone. Thank you.
Madam President, Madam Vice President, dear colleagues, the budgetary control has uncovered no new topics.
We are satisfied with the old and would also be satisfied with advancements on the old topics.
Five points first. Our urgent request for support for Romania and Bulgaria in establishing the rule of law, the judiciary, and financial oversight.
We do not wish to be where we are today in two years’ time, and therefore this point is very, very important to us.
The second point concerns the reliability statement for the overall budget following the tiered control procedure, involving the national audit offices.
It would be desirable if we could achieve decisive progress here in the last six months, which is all that remains for the Commission, or at the very least agree on a common path.
One becomes modest as a budget controller.
The third point would be the simplification.
We must provide greater assistance to the member states’ lower levels of administration in the implementation of EU law.
It becomes apparent that they are completely overwhelmed by large portions of EU law. This explains the high error rates.
The fourth point, external assistance, here I would primarily like to address Kosovo and the question of cooperation with the United Nations.
The Committee on Budgetary Control has been in Kosovo, and I would now like to announce that Kosovo will play a certain role in the discharge procedure.
I believe that we have remained far below the possibilities of the European Union thus far, and that we urgently need to revisit this.
The fifth point would be the improvement of cooperation among the member states in the fight against fraud.
We have here homework, primarily for the members of the council.
The Parliament will vote on the legal basis, the regulation for fraud prevention, in November, and then we must jointly consider how we proceed if we wish to achieve better results in this field.
And that has been, at least until now, our shared desire.
Thank you, Mr. President. India and Europe need more and better contacts with each other at all levels, especially also at the level of so-called ordinary people.
Business travelers, tourists, students, and so forth. A brief note on that. It is also relevant to the Commission's legislative program, which we discussed earlier.
In global air traffic, we need good safety regulations. Regulations that achieve something and are not mere window dressing.
It would therefore be a reasonable, genuinely necessary measure to finally abolish the pointless regulations concerning liquids and devise something better.
I voted for the resolution because it is a clear call to the Belarusian government to finally respect human rights.

It is disappointing that the hopes for a democratic development for the people of this last European dictatorship were not fulfilled by the questionable, indeed fraudulent, parliamentary elections of September.
The same applies to the strategic suppression of opposition as well as civil society.
At the same time, we have today urged the Council and the Commission to facilitate and intensify contacts between peoples and to democratize the country by seriously considering the possibility of a
Reduction of visa fees for Belarusian citizens, in order to facilitate their entry into the Schengen Area and thereby prevent increasing isolation of Belarus and its citizens.
I would like, first of all, to object to the spirit of a statement heard only a few minutes ago, that foreigners would inundate our labor market.
And secondly, I would have wished for a clearer, more definitive report from the Employment Committee.
Trust in the European Union’s capacity for social cohesion can only be achieved if fundamental social rights are defined as European primary law.

We should send a stronger signal to the Council, the Commission, the Member States, and the Court of Justice of the European Union and not be satisfied with merely demanding a balance between fundamental rights and internal market freedoms, and the free movement of goods, services, capital, and persons.
That changes nothing. Social basic rights, just like freedom rights, are human rights that must not be restricted by flexibilities of the internal market.
And it is about defending and improving the European social model. And it is high time to introduce a social progress clause as a binding protocol to the existing EU treaties.
And it is time to amend the Posted Workers Directive so that wage and minimum standards requirements may not be limited to minimum requirements. Thank you.
Thank you, Mr. President. I would like to join the thanks to the rapporteur, Doris Back, which has already been expressed by many colleagues, and quite rightly so.
We have with her someone who, hopefully, won’t pour their heart and soul into it, but will invest a great deal of passion in this space.
I am pleased with her and the colleagues who also said so, that there have been some advances, also in the area of police cooperation.
This is important so that actual life on the ground can also function in a reasonable manner.

However, I still believe that we must repeatedly remind our interlocutors in Bosnia and Herzegovina that they themselves, from their side, still need to contribute considerably, perhaps even more than is currently being contributed in certain areas.
Internal collaboration, the willingness to engage in this internal collaboration among ethnicities, is something that we must consistently demand.
It is not a matter of everyone attempting to forge their own path.
and also the integration into the regional cooperation in the Western Balkans is important.
Thank you, Madam President. The distance between the European Union and its citizens must not become as great as it has.
We need to ensure that it is reduced in size.
In this context, the citizen’s representative has an important role to play, especially when and where they perform it well.
It is primarily also about reckoning with the commitment and judiciousness of the Citizens' Representative.
It is about ensuring that we do not raise expectations that cannot then be met.

It is also about ensuring that wherever grievances have arisen within the administrative bodies of the European Union, they are addressed and, wherever possible, reasonable solutions are sought that can guarantee and satisfy citizens.
Past practice has demonstrated that the citizen's representative undertakes this task seriously and effectively.
We can only hope that this will continue to be the case, and we thank him and the rapporteur for this report.
Thank you very much.
Dear colleagues, ten years after the realization of the monetary union, Europe finds itself in a severe crisis.
Banks collapse or are propped up with billions from the state budget. Sales slump and millions of people fear for their jobs and their future.
But not only has the market failed. The prevailing politics also appear incapable of learning from their mistakes.

We are of the opinion – though we do not intend to suggest that you wish to unduly distinguish yourself with such asides – that grave errors were committed in the construction of the Economic and Monetary Union.
Such an error is the structural divergence of monetary and fiscal policy. One cannot create a common currency without simultaneously harmonizing tax and expenditure policy to at least some degree.
I believe that the economic imbalances within the Eurozone have intensified considerably.
And what we now need is, in fact, better coordination of the economy and, above all, tax policy.
We need effective measures against tax dumping. Furthermore, tax havens must be closed and capital flows finally controlled again.
The second significant error lies in the construction of the Stability and Growth Pact.

Anyone who believes a consolidation of households is indispensable in times like these clearly lives in a different world. Nothing would be more fatal than reacting to this economic crisis now with public austerity programs.
The Stability Pact has definitively proven its failure.
It should be replaced by an integrated European strategy for solidarity and sustainable development.
In our view, an investment offensive is needed to renew public infrastructure and to improve the situation of those socially disadvantaged in Europe.
A third error lies in the construction of the European Central Bank itself, which is not subject to democratic control and is solely committed to the goal of price stability.

We advocate for the democratic control of the European Central Bank. Furthermore, we demand a correction of the ECB’s monetary policy mandate, whereby growth and employment must be promoted at least equally with price stability in the future.
The present crisis also offers an opportunity for profound reforms of the European monetary and financial architecture.
This opportunity should not be lightly squandered.
Thank you, Madam President, Commissioner, President of the Council, esteemed colleagues. Indeed, the automotive industry is in a crisis, and there are many reasons for this.
In particular, the financial crisis has further accelerated the crisis in this sector, and at present, member states are working on solutions.
The European automotive industry is a key industry.
Therefore, we need European solutions for this key European industry to manage the crisis.
Almost all automotive corporations have European structures.

To make necessary investments in environmentally friendly cars, as has been mentioned several times here today, and to implement environmentally sound and fuel-efficient technologies, automakers require public guarantees or low-interest loans from the European Investment Bank.
But also the supplier industry must not be forgotten in this regard.
Precisely in the supplier industry, it is small and medium-sized enterprises where jobs are created and where innovations take place.
But what can the European Union do to protect this key industry?
In the previous plenary session, the President of the Council made a proposal to protect key industries.
A good proposal, as I see it. If one consistently pursues this thought, this proposal to its logical conclusion, it means a Volkswagen Act for the entire European automotive industry.
and this would certainly be a useful instrument.
But this protective measure is currently being challenged by the European Commission.

And now to my question to the Commission. Will the European Commission maintain its commitment to a legal challenge despite the crisis in the automotive industry? Or is this course of action being reconsidered in light of the crisis?
Dear Mr. President, Mr. President of the European Court of Auditors, Mr. Vice-President of the European Commission, esteemed colleagues, it has indeed become a tradition to observe
must not be the case that in the relationship between expenditure at the European level and administration at the national level, a declaration of assurance cannot repeatedly be given.

I recall conversations with the former President of the Federal Audit Court, Professor Friedmann, who once told me that, due to the structures in place, it is simply not possible to provide a reliability declaration.
Therefore, we should already consider together how this instrument can also be brought to life in such a way that the goal of a reliability declaration, if justified, can also be achieved.
And here, of course, we must already distinguish a few things from one another.
Firstly, a budget encompassing approximately 95% subsidies is significantly more susceptible to fraud than a national, regional, or municipal budget.

A subsidy budget that is essentially managed by the Member States, who, in the new funding period, have demanded a great deal more autonomy from us, because the criticism of the previous funding period was that it was being overly centrally controlled.
That naturally also means that responsibility for the money must be assumed regionally and nationally.
And in the third thematic area, I would like to address only briefly.
We must also learn to distinguish between fraud and waste.
These too are things that are habitually thrown together.
I am also annoyed when EU funds are used to support things that are not strictly necessary.
That, however, was not fraud; that was wastefulness.

Therefore, those responsible for projects, particularly in the area of structural policy, also bear the responsibility towards the Member States to ensure that funds are not squandered and that only projects are supported which genuinely create added value for the region.
Therefore, we should also consider restructuring parts of regional development policy to utilize interest-free loans.
For if Member States have to repay, then they only fund what they genuinely need. Thank you very much.
It is not just I who find it difficult to concur with this burgeoning self-praise of European decision-makers when it comes to managing the financial market crisis.
Were Europe to be a functioning democracy within this EU, one would first need to address the question of responsibility and how all of this could have come about.
It is simply not true that all the problems we now face represent a tsunami, something dictated by the laws of nature, but rather are the product of human action.
And amidst all the regulatory zeal that has characterized this Union, one wonders why action was not taken, to a significant degree, when banks began to cross national borders.
Why was no action taken despite appropriate warnings as the derivatives infiltrated?
I remember very well that Nobel laureate Josef Stieglitz was here, addressing all these points.
There was a silence, there was a taboo.
That is precisely where one must begin, because recognizing one’s own errors is the sole key to finding solutions in the future.
Thank you, Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen, Mr. Commissioner, my question concerns what you think about Iceland and Hungary introducing the euro as a secondary currency.
Do you believe that this could solve the problem of these two countries?
The second question is whether you believe it would be possible to introduce a risk premium for derivatives, which would then be used to strengthen the banks' capital base and
My third question is, don't you think a reduction in value-added tax would correspondingly support imports, particularly from China and India?

wouldn't it be more sensible to consider tax reductions for our businesses and for our employees, that investment premiums are paid, that the progressive depreciation is correspondingly brought into the
The focus is on increasing primarily low-value assets by a factor of 10, so that apparent profits are not taxed, the money remains within the ventures, and consequently, higher wages can be paid.
Thank you, Madam President. The comprehensive report highlights how many human rights violations occur around the world every day.
This is particularly alarming 60 years after the declaration of the Charter of Human Rights and calls on us to intensify our efforts.
For this reason as well, I would like to advocate for establishing the current Subcommittee on Human Rights as the main committee.
Today, we have awarded the Sakharov Prize to Hu Jia, who advocates for human rights and the environment in China.
Because he is currently detained, he could not take personal possession of it.
Shame on China! And tomorrow, a debate on human rights violations in Russia will take place here.
In our relations with these two countries, we must accord not only economic interests, but above all human rights a higher priority.
We demand freedom for Hujia in China and freedom for Michael Khodorkovsky in Russia.

Mr. President, esteemed members of the Council, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues, as rapporteur for the Anti-Fraud Office, one makes interesting observations, such as the fact that everyone talks about anti-fraud measures, and then no one acts.
Or the experience that Member States meticulously calculate their payments to the European Union, but when it comes to spending this money, they loosen the purse strings.
and even make it easy for fraudsters. For example, because, on average, it still takes 36 months before irregularities are even reported to the European Union.
The European Parliament does not agree with this.
We want an efficient fraud prevention program that also includes preventative measures.
We want the member states to make fraud prevention a priority and that we discuss together the necessities and challenges involved.
We seek greater engagement from national judicial authorities in the subsequent prosecution of OLA mediation outcomes.
In non-linear routes, there must no longer be free right-hand spaces as previously.
We require parity between European currency and national currency.
We desire an independent office that possesses the necessary resources and legal basis to fulfill its tasks.
And we want an office that can work quietly and efficiently with the member states.
Our position regarding the legal basis 1073-99 addresses all of these points.
We advocate for further developing this regulation as a core component of the Office for Countering Fraud, together with the Council.

We urge the Council to incorporate our observations.
We urge the Council to initiate discussions on the further development of this regulation.
We want to bring Olaf’s problems to a resolution.
And I thank all factions of this Chamber who are also supporting this in a resolution that we will vote on tomorrow.
I appeal to the French and Czech Council Presidencies to take up and return the ball of Parliament.
We have also incorporated solutions developed and submitted by the Council working group into our proposals.
On our side, I am authorized to express our interest in a swift conclusion of this regulation and to assure you of our willingness to engage in constructive discussions based on our proposals.
A consolidation of all Olaf legal bases, as the Council intended, would mean a further considerable loss of time with an uncertain outcome.
Olaf will soon celebrate his tenth birthday.
Consolidation means another ten years without an improved legal basis.
For us, combating fraud is too important.
We intend, therefore, to realize what is feasible now in collaboration with the Council.
Thank you very much.
Mr. President, I would like to take up a point raised earlier by my Austrian colleague, Paul Rübig.

We spend less than one percent of European gross domestic product on Europe. Simultaneously, we demand that an ever-increasing number of tasks for an ever-increasing number of member states be handled by the European Union.

This calculation cannot be correct. It is therefore also truly implausible if we have been pursuing an austerity policy for many years. But the austerity policy not only in the thrifty sales administration,
to utilize our funds, but fundamentally, to ensure that, at the end of the year, the finance ministers again collect funds and channel them into their respective budgets.
We would have enough new tasks for which we should expend our money.
We also have tasks that we have not truly funded appropriately from a budgetary perspective for years.
I believe that the European Union’s information funding should be significantly increased if we genuinely wish to connect European citizens to Europe.
and there are a great many tasks in the area of student and trainee exchange that Europe could undertake.
also advances in the judicial sector, an area traditionally reserved for the state.
This corresponds to the altered living conditions of the people in our Union.
However, and this observation has been made several times, integration must not intrude excessively upon traditionally established structures, particularly those that are functioning effectively.
Not everything can be swept under the rug.
Public deeds and public notaries are configured quite differently in many Member States.
In Austria, but not exclusively within our country, the notary public has a long tradition as a public registrar and enjoys a high level of security and trust.
This must not be risked unnecessarily, simply because such professional groups do not exist elsewhere.
Therefore, integration and reciprocal openness, yes, but with discretion.
Thank you, Madam President. Esteemed colleagues, plant protection products have been and remain essential operating resources in agriculture.
Farmers require a minimum selection of plant protection products, as this concerns the preservation of the native cultural landscape, high-quality nutrition, and the protection of resources.
We discuss chemicals far too often on a very irrational level.
To obtain sensible results, however, we must think and act rationally.
The consequences of the initial parliamentary position would have been fatal. A broad ban on pesticides would have resulted in lower agricultural yields and, ultimately, rising food prices.
Therefore, I am pleased that a barely acceptable compromise was found in the trilogue negotiations.
It is commendable that we have maintained the three-zone system, albeit with significant exceptions for the member states.

A courageous step towards a consistent solution for the internal market would look different in this instance. Besides the acceptable compromises, we should not preempt a final definition of endocrine-disrupting substances, but rather actually give the EU Commission the four years to present a scientifically sound definition.
Otherwise, we would be overextending the precautionary principle at this point.
Finally, I find it regrettable that we allow ourselves to be dissuaded from initiating a follow-up assessment of the agreement reached now. Thank you again.
When last, during the visit of a head of government or head of state, similar expressions of opinion arose, the President of this House intervened decisively.
At that time, it concerned a matter that was important to him personally, namely the Lisbon Treaty.
When today the President, the sovereignly elected President of a country, speaks and is massively interrupted and disturbed by the socialist side, the President does not proceed.
Do you know what this is?
That is not democracy; it is arbitrary rule, and I call for appropriate measures to be taken.
Children and politics – rarely do the interests of citizens and politicians diverge so greatly.
For citizens across Europe, the issue of childhood stands paramount.
For politicians, children's concerns rank among distant considerations, as we can ascertain once again here.
I know of no country that has its own ministry for children. Nor does the commission have a dedicated representative for the interests of our youngest citizens.
In Parliament, the topic of childhood has been scattered across all committees.
Therefore, I would like to particularly highlight to the Commission at this juncture that it is addressing childcare facilities and the Barcelona Goals today.
Thank you. In our parliamentary working group Quality of Childhood, we have ascertained the following. Our children live in a very complex world.
The future of a person who is a child here, now, and today is entirely uncertain.
A child of today can climb to the very top of the social scale or fall very far down.
It can remain within its own cultural circle or seek a new one.
It can follow a similar life path as its parents or do precisely the opposite.
One may marry someone of the opposite or same gender.
All of that was very different more than 50 years ago, when we christened the united Europe.
The diversity that distinguishes us Europeans, this diversity has become a defining factor in children's lives.
The concept of diversity must therefore find its way into the pedagogy of childcare providers and teachers.
This is currently far too little considered.
European childcare facilities and schools are struggling with the challenge of integration.
In integration matters, we must press the reset button, back to the start.
Let us approach this topic once again entirely free of preconceptions, in accordance with the motto “Unity through Diversity.”

Furthermore, I ask all my successor Members of the European Parliament: do not only advocate for gender mainstreaming, but also fight for child mainstreaming, especially now during this time of global financial crisis, because otherwise we will burden our children with immeasurable debt. Thank you.
Thank you, Mr. President. I will keep this very brief.
I am very grateful for these constructive contributions to the debate that I have heard here.

I would like to send out only two messages in conclusion. Firstly, I would like to express my explicit gratitude to the Commissioner for not having spoken fundamentally against the concept of minimum requirements for the safety net.
This proposal is neither a devilish scheme nor a bureaucratic monster.
He is a problem-solving tool to which we should give a chance.
Therefore, I would simply like to advocate for that once again at this point.
And the second thing I’d like to say, and this is now directed to my British friends, is across all the parties.
My dear British friends, I do understand Caroline. I do understand your problem.
I can well understand that one might prioritize a country's energy security for a certain period over adherence to an air pollutant limit.
I have considerable understanding of that.
I am also the last person who would deny Your Majesty additional time when it comes to constructing new coal-fired power plants.
We can talk about it, can’t we?
The problem is, we didn't do precisely that.
This conversation has never taken place during the last four months.
I would like to ask you to be open-minded at this point—this is now the outlook for the second reading—and to say, let us discuss a compromise at this point.

for which to relinquish the, from my perspective, entirely irrational resistance, the competition policy and environmental policy-based resistance that is not justifiable, the fundamental opposition to the minimum standards.
I believe this is the point where a compromise can be reached, one that I hope we will also secure in the second reading at the end.
Incidentally, I do not believe that we should avoid seeking a compromise in a first reading.
For this, the legislation is too complex.
I do not wish to conclude this legislative term as rapporteur and leave a piece of legislation to the next parliament, consisting of a text that is inconsistent, illogical, and contradictory.
Therefore, I request your support for the compromises when we vote here in one hour. Thank you.
Dear colleagues, I believe the crucial question regarding all the economic stimulus programs currently being finalized across Europe is, of course, who ultimately receives the funding?
Will further blank checks be issued to the banks, even though the rapid nationalization would ultimately be significantly cheaper for the taxpayer?
And should corporations and high-income earners be further relieved, despite already having been fattened for years across Europe through tax breaks?

The more money is squandered for such purposes, the more predictable the failure of these programs becomes, and the more likely it is that the European economy will sink further and further into a very dangerous downward spiral.

The decades-long policy of privatization, deregulation, and liberalization—precisely this policy—has increasingly concentrated incomes among the top 10,000. And it was this policy that is responsible for the current crisis in which we find ourselves today.
And whoever believes that this crisis can be overcome by continuing precisely this policy with minor modifications, I think that person simply doesn't understand anything at all.
The precise opposite is required.
Instead of purchasing bad debts from banks, tax revenue should be used for the renovation of schools, hospitals, and for the ecological restructuring of the European economy.

If private companies receive public funds, it must be stipulated that no tax money be disbursed without employment guarantees and, above all, without the acquisition of public property rights, so that the state and, in particular, the general public can later participate in future earnings.
The very best economic stimulus program currently conceivable would be a radical redistribution of income and assets from the top downwards.
The sector of exploitative low wages in Europe must be curtailed, rather than further encouraged.
We need higher minimum wages. We need better social benefits in Europe.

And we need taxes that ensure that millionaires and the profiteers of the past financial market boom now also bear the immense losses that have occurred. And not the vast majority of citizens who, after all, never benefited from the entire financial boom.
I believe that what is socially just is currently also the economically most sensible.
And it is the only way to break through the devastating crisis dynamics.

Thank you, Mr. President. At the beginning of March, the political prisoners Michael Chodorkowski and Platon Lebedev were transferred from Chita in Siberia to Moscow to be indicted once again on the basis of untenable charges.
The first day of public hearings has been scheduled for March 31.
On the same day, human rights consultations between the EU and Russia were scheduled to take place.
These important discussions have now been postponed indefinitely by the Russian side.
Russia is thereby demonstrating very clearly the low priority it affords to human rights.
The judiciary will continue not only to fail to deliver justice, but will be employed to neutralize regime opponents, thereby deceiving the EU.

Thank you very much, Mr. Commissioner. Thank you very much, dear colleagues. I am particularly grateful to Mr. Commissioner Verheugen for once again pointing out the prohibition of animal experimentation.

has pointed out, because it reminds me that this is now the third amendment to cosmetic legislation that I have been privileged to witness. The sixth amendment, the seventh amendment, and now the transition to a regulation.
And we have, in fact, managed to prohibit animal testing.
We have managed to ensure that, for example, consumers know how long a product remains shelf-stable by seeing a small container with a number indicating its remaining validity period.

I say this also to the address of some colleagues, particularly to the colleague Reuthofer, who unfortunately could not be present at the beginning. Markings are never warnings, at no time. If a product were not safe, then it must not be on the market, then it must not be marketed.
Every product present on this European market must be safe and harmless.
But the labeling provides consumers with the opportunity to select.
That is democracy, and that is its freedom of choice.
I believe that we have very good legislation.
I have endeavored to design the procedure in a very transparent manner.
I have attempted, as Ms. Kostet also stated, to bring together differing opinions.

for I am concerned that we create legislation that is good for all, for consumers in the European Union, for the industry that must work with this legislation, and ultimately for all those who will benefit from it.
I will reiterate to colleague Schnellhardt that yes, the deodorant affects each person differently, but the claim that it keeps them sweat-free is nonetheless made.
And therefore, it is important that the statements regarding my crease depth around the eyes are also reasonably realistic and reliable after one week in Strasbourg.
I would like to reiterate my thanks to the Commissioner, also regarding the explanations he provided, to my colleagues, and to my employee, who did the majority of the work.
I am very grateful to you.

Madam President, Madam Commissioner, esteemed colleagues, the report by Mr. Van Nistelrooy concerning the Green Paper and the future shape of coalition policy is undoubtedly one of the most significant of the Committee of the Regions in recent years.
And we agree with the fundamental concept of the Green Paper, according to which territorial cohesion is essentially about counteracting the polycentric development of the EU.
overall, to ensure sustainable development of the territories with their various characteristics and specific features, while also preserving their diversity.
And it is correct that in the next planning period, a more comprehensive system of phased assistance for transitional regions, exceeding the threshold of 75 to 100 meters,
must be created so that these regions receive a distinct status and, consequently, greater security in their development.

And in the report by colleague Kree regarding obstacles to the drawdown of Structural Funds, the most significant shortcomings are rightly listed, shortcomings for which applicants are no longer responsible when drawing down Structural Funds.
Stand as a consequence of utilizing structural funds, such as excessive administrative costs, too many complex regulations, and slow and cumbersome centralized administration in the member states.
And numerous recommendations are made to the Commission regarding the measures that should be taken to reduce these obstacles.
I would simply like to highlight and reaffirm two such measures.
Firstly. Currently, project managers are required to retain their project documentation for a period of ten years, to have it available should inspections be conducted, potentially by the Commission.
Especially for smaller projects, it represents an excessively bureaucratic effort.
Indeed, that is now to be reduced to a period of three years. And secondly, the EU Commission’s evaluation criteria for innovative projects pose significant challenges.
In innovative projects, different assessment criteria should apply than for other projects.
It is simply necessary that something different occurs here.

Thank you, Madam President. If Europe puts money on the table and if, above all, the member states put a great deal of money on the table to assist the automotive industry in its crisis situation, then it cannot be solely about securing existing structures and the status quo and preventing bankruptcies, but about a range of other concerns.
The most important ones have been mentioned.
It is about helping people find employment. They also need to secure that employment, and do so in the long term.
For this, it is necessary that we promote new technologies, innovation, and above all, sustainability within the transportation system more strongly than we have done so far.

Therefore, we should link all our measures to these objectives, so that we are not obliged in a few years to acknowledge that we should have thought of all this many years ago – otherwise, we would find ourselves in the next and new crisis.
Thank you, Madam President. It would be appreciated if you would also grant me the additional half-minute that my Green colleague, Ms. Breyer, just received.
The Commission had submitted a sound proposal for updating the regulation on novel foods.

Unfortunately, some proposed amendments attempt to supplement this proposal with stipulations that are incompatible with the objectives of the regulation or even seek to intervene in existing case law.
The obligation of food business operators to monitor novel foods with regard to the health and welfare of animals would simply overwhelm the retailers.
Once again, there is an attempt to undermine existing GMO regulations, namely the demand for specific labeling of novel foods derived from animals that have been fed genetically modified feed.
We have just heard it.
Generally, everything pertaining to GMO legislation should not be addressed within the Novel Food Regulation.
I say this, although I myself, for instance, had proposed distinguishing specific new plant species from the definition of novel foods.
But it cannot be the case that interested parties within this institution are abusing the Novel Food Regulation for campaign purposes.
It appears that amendment proposals 62 and 90 also represent such an attempt, for which the Green Party has requested a roll-call vote.
Colleagues, what precisely do you intend to expose?
My faction has always championed the consumer's right to know what is contained in food.
Why, then, should one not indicate a nano origin on the ingredient declaration?
And although amendment 62 rather clumsily attempts to anticipate my report on food labeling, I must tell you that I consider this labeling of Novel Food to be entirely compatible with my report.

I therefore recommend to my parliamentary group that they approve the aforementioned proposals, and I will include in my report on the food labelling regulation references to the part of the Novel Food Regulation that deals with labelling.
This is possible because we have postponed the first reading on foot labeling to the next legislative term, against the wishes of the Green Party.
But now it is clear to everyone how advantageous this postponement proved to be.
Briefly regarding cloning, it constitutes animal cruelty.
We are opposed.
Nevertheless, foodstuffs must be incorporated into this regulation accordingly, because otherwise they would be in a…
Thank you, Madam President.
Whoever does not wish for this man to chair the solemn opening session of the European Parliament should support my proposal to amend the Rules of Procedure. Thank you.

Thank you very much, Madam President, Madam President, dear Commissioner, esteemed colleagues. One thing I want to state clearly at the outset: the provision of food to those in need, particularly in these economically challenging times, is not open to debate for me in the upcoming vote on the report by our colleague Schikirski.
Therefore, I also want to make it clear from the outset that finding a common line within our parliamentary group was not easy.
Therefore, respect the personal decision of each parliamentary colleague to deviate and not to agree with the rejection of the report that we have planned.
Why can I not approve of the committee vote’s result in this form?

There are a number of reasons for this, which have absolutely nothing, not even the slightest thing, to do with assistance for those in need within the European Union during these economically challenging times.

Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen, we, too, fundamentally welcome the proposal of the European Commission and this Grünbach book.

There is, and this is not a matter of debate, a mass phenomenon that has been described by the various previous speakers, namely, where relatively minor damages occur among a large number of affected parties.
The damage to those directly affected is small, but when aggregated, it is substantial.
An instrument is required to address this problem and
It is, in my estimation, correct that consideration is given to such matters.

I also greatly welcome the fact, to remain positive, that the Directorate-General for Consumer Protection has placed a decisive focus in its Green Paper on the question of alternative dispute resolution mechanisms.

This represents a significant difference from the White Paper of the Directorate-General for Competition, also discussed here yesterday, which has hitherto completely disregarded the possibility of extrajudicial dispute resolution mechanisms.
I believe that here, the Directorate-General for Consumer Protection goes further in its Green Paper than its competition colleagues.
However, I want to make two things quite clear as well, which, in my view, should certainly be understood as critical observations.
The Parliament will decide, here at 12 o’clock, in a few minutes, on my report concerning the White Paper of the Directorate-General for Competition.
We will, with a large majority in this House, demand of the European Commission that a horizontal approach be chosen when dealing with this matter.
It cannot be the case that we end up with sectoral instruments, one for consumer protection, one for antitrust law, another for the capital market, and perhaps one more for the environment.

Perhaps one more concerning social policy – they all contradict each other. They all intervene in the legal order of the member states and ultimately lead to a policy muddle that no practitioner can manage.
We have often had such examples in the past.
Consider only the debate concerning the professional qualifications directive, which we subsequently consolidated into an instrument as well, because this fragmentation had become unmanageable.
The commission should not make the same mistake here.
I should have promoted a horizontal approach from the outset.
This is the clear stance of the Parliament; it will become evident here in a few months, in a few minutes.

One final point. I also very much welcome the fact that we have reached a consensus that we do not want a litigation industry modeled on the American system, generating $240 billion in annual revenue, in which only lawyers ultimately benefit and the consumer receives nothing.
We want genuine rule of law in Europe and to remain true to our traditional systems and our understanding of law. Thank you.
Dear colleagues, there are many ways to manage the sustainable consequences of the unexpected financial and economic crisis.

Provisions within the framework of the Structural Funds Regulation, following a request, dear colleagues, repeatedly made by the European Parliament in recent years.

to invest in structural policy funding in energy efficiency and renewable energy in residential construction. And that these measures should not only be available to households with low incomes.

Guidance from resources of the European Regional Development Fund (ERDF), the European Social Fund (ESF), and the Cohesion Fund, and a simplification of the regulations enabling rapid programme implementation, are in place.

Thank you, Madam President. Esteemed colleagues, in principle, I welcome the European Ecolabel.

The symbol will only establish itself in the future if there are clear criteria and standards that precede its acquisition.

The incentive principle must be paramount.
It would be regrettable if the establishment of the eco-label were to fail due to bureaucratic obstacles.
Ultimately, the consumer determines success or failure, as acceptance must be achieved with them.

Even though I am personally very fond of the Blue Angel, as we have it in Germany, it must ultimately not be a matter of personal taste, but rather it is essential that consumers are immediately informed about the specific characteristics of a product at a glance.
A benefit for the consumer arises only when the member states relinquish their respective national signs and, ultimately, a unified sign at the European level exists.
A jumble of symbols unsettles the consumer and fails to inform them.
A sign, a statement—this is what we should work on together. Thank you.

and are and were the Members of Parliament who are now here, who over the last five years have ensured that the necessary reforms, in a variety of areas, were achieved in the interest of the Members of Parliament.

And I explain to you why I arrive at this word.

The proposal under consideration essentially fulfills only one promise.

When we come to what happens to the artists themselves and their income, and we calculate that, then we arrive at
such low average sums that it in no way serves as a livelihood for an artist, enabling him to make a living from it.

And the fund is too small to achieve anything.
An artist with whom I discussed this has told me that here, a redistribution from the living to the dead is taking place.
I had to contradict him. It is a redistribution of funds from the artists to the producers, to the music industry, and specifically to the major players.
All in all, Mr. Commissioner, this proposal is not suitable.
We must find better ones.

Thank you, Mr. President. I share the Rapporteur Gilles Savary’s regret that the Commission has abandoned its original plan for a comprehensive action plan.
There are many good reasons why all stakeholders, from municipalities to the European Union, are striving to improve urban traffic conditions.
We know that most people in Europe live in cities and that the current traffic conditions are anything but optimal.
Therefore, fundamental agreement with the plan and the report of the colleague Savary, to develop corresponding integrated proposals from the Parliament's initiative here.
I thank him for his commitment and also for the specific suggestions.
At the same time, however, I want to signal with utmost clarity that what many fear or believe they must fear will not come to pass.
No one wishes to take away from municipalities, from local and regional territorial authorities, their right to shape their traffic conditions.

From the European side, we merely wish to contribute to ensuring that proceedings are conducted according to sensible, common rules, when a municipality, a city, or a regional unit deems this sensible.
The principle of subsidiarity is not jeopardized,
What we aim to do here is to safeguard this principle.
It therefore remains that we, in the interest of citizens, strive to ensure that, when a citizen is 10, 20 kilometers within
Europe continues onward, only to encounter a traffic-calmed zone that he believes he knows from his home community, and there discovers entirely different rules governing it.
No community will be compelled to adopt city tolls or other regulations, but if they are implemented here, they should be formulated within a discernible framework for the citizens.
For more than 100 years, we have agreed on the rationale of coordinated approaches regarding traffic signs.
That should also be the case with this topic in the future.
Thank you, Mr. President. We have been dealing with urban transport within the EU for quite some time now.
Why actually?

We are simply not responsible for this. Jurisdiction was initially established because approximately 80 percent of the population lives in urban areas and, due to the climate debate, there was a desire to address the matter.
Well, fortunately, we were able to reduce these ambitions of the European Commission to an action plan for urban transport through our protest.
And I thank Commissioner Tajani for his understanding.

Subsidizing, after all, tends more towards supporting than prescribing, but that was something an Italian, naturally, understood better than I, as a German with only a single, grand Latin qualification.
It is primarily important to me that our report, the report of Parliament, emphasizes the strict adherence to the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality.
Legislative measures at the European level are impermissible for urban transport.
Supportive measures. That is our task.
A collection of ideas and the promotion of the exchange of best practices is advisable.
Not everyone needs to reinvent the wheel.
Our cities need tailored solutions, but these can only be developed by the stakeholders on site, for they alone know what is necessary.
Municipalities must respond to very different situations. They therefore require sufficient scope for action, also in order to maintain the vitality of inner-city retail.
That is important for the appeal of a city.
It is therefore important not to exclude motorized individual transport and to focus more on urban logistics.
I would therefore like to see research into inner-city enemy distribution supported.
That eases the burden on a city.
It is also important to consider demographic change.
Our society is ultimately growing older.
Mobility needs and housing requirements are changing.
We need local provision of everyday goods for the population if we want to reduce traffic. And that also presents a challenge for the retail sector.
Anything else would only demand the green meadow.
Finally, we do not require an observation point for urban traffic.
Such a position would cost a great deal of money and produce a great deal of paperwork, which would only be filed in Brussels. Thank you very much.
I fully support the Commission’s objective of establishing a legal framework for the coordinated implementation and use of intelligent transport systems in road traffic.

My years-long personal struggle for the standard-issue introduction of eCall, the electronic emergency call system, underscores the urgency for me almost daily. Yet, intelligent transport systems can achieve much more.
They contribute to environmental compatibility, efficiency enhancement, improved safety, and non-discriminatory competitiveness in road freight and passenger transport.

Furthermore, they support co-modality, among other things, through the development of interfaces to other modes of transport such as rail, waterways, and air transport, where the integration of intelligent transport systems has already begun.
All of this cannot be achieved by the member states alone, but only as a shared task.

Intelligent transport systems, based on EU-wide, binding, fundamental standards and regulations regarding minimum quality, improve the environment for innovation and create planning certainty, particularly for small and medium-sized enterprises.
I particularly welcome the planned open, vehicle-integrated platform for intelligent transportation system services.
The action plan now includes a schedule for the introduction of individual systems. A for road safety such as ESP and eCall. B for continuity in traffic management. For example, information regarding
Avoid toll charges or parking management traffic. c. The use of real-time road, traffic, and travel data will benefit not only professional drivers, but all road users.
The Directive aims to establish detailed requirements for the uniformly binding and coordinated introduction of intelligent transport systems across the EU and their application in the Member States.
It also safeguards the handling of personal data.

However, caution! The introduction of intelligent transport systems incurs high costs, as infrastructures and vehicles first need to be equipped with the necessary information and communication technologies.
We know too little about the willingness and ability to pay of potential users.

There must never again be a debate in Europe about life worth living and life not worth living.
In Europe, there should be no political or social pressure on parents to consciously decide against having a child with a disability.
The selection of embryos would be a major ethical rupture.
Therefore, this amendment must be rejected. And it is not enough to simply eliminate the word—the term "schreichen"—which, unfortunately, does indeed correspond to fascist-like language.
but it would still be a matter of selection of embryos.

We must decisively counter genetic discrimination.
Therefore, Amendment 15 must be rejected in its entirety. Otherwise, our faction would unfortunately also be compelled to vote against this report, which is otherwise quite positive.
Thank you, Mr. President. For the first time since becoming a member of this assembly, I voted against the discharge of the Commission in the vote concerning the discharge, and would like to
to explain my reasons. My primary concern is the manner in which the European Commission handled the accession of the two new countries, Romania and Bulgaria.
We are confronted with a variety of problems in Romania and Bulgaria, with a high level of corruption, with a great deal of money, with a great deal of European money that has disappeared.
The European Commission only began freezing these funds in 2008.
In 2007, we lost a significant amount of money, and now we are dealing with either virtually non-existent control systems or systems that function only intermittently.
In Romania, we are dealing with a high rate of corruption and problems within the judiciary.
All of this is attributable to the pre-accession process.

My aim is to set a precedent, also to tell the European Commission that it must proceed differently with future accessions and to point out that, as has been observed in other countries, it could certainly be more successful if it were to do so.
I would like to urge the Commission to assist the two countries in establishing financial control systems that merit the name and that help eliminate systemic weaknesses in these two countries.
Otherwise, we would have a persistent problem and a perpetual source of concern hanging around Europe’s neck. Thank you very much.

some examples. There is a permit for the use of specific material from Category 1 in pet food.

The Stockholm Programme sails completely past the real challenges of the present.
The fundamental flaw is that a Europe of rights is being established, which is to be granted to EU citizens, but not to other people who live in Europe.
And these same civil and human rights are not to be granted to them.
On the one hand, the EU wishes to accede to the Charter of Fundamental Rights, which we welcome; but on the other hand, migrants are sorted according to the principle of legal or illegal.
Thus, Frontex is being bolstered for the massive combating of so-called illegal migration. And I tell you, this completely distorts the perspective on an unbiased immigration policy.
Here, Stockholm fails.
Another problem is the entirely imbalanced relationship between security and freedom.
Yes, there is no freedom without security, but there is also no security without freedom. Freedom is not a bargaining chip, but a universal right of every human being.

Stockholm, conversely, symbolizes the EU’s obsession with security, in which massive supranational databases are created without sufficient oversight mechanisms, merging intelligence and police data across Europe.
This will make the right to informational self-determination of individuals, obsolescence, and the vision of a transparent person a reality.

Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, a microfinance instrument for the unemployed, for those threatened by unemployment, and especially for people who lack access to conventional credit markets, is a good intention and is supported in principle by our parliamentary group.
However, what the Commission and Council have achieved in terms of performance in this process is simply inadequate, partly incorrect, and cannot be supported by our group.
First point of criticism: the question of financial resources.
What is on the table in terms of financial resources is not financial support for an unemployment reduction program. This cannot be described as a microfinance program. At best, it is nanofinance.
Secondly, we are fundamentally opposed to performing such sleight of hand, without any effect, that comes at the expense of other programs and thus dissipate endlessly.
Thirdly, the conception, sustainability, and success of such a program must inherently include organic mentoring and coaching.
Many new start-ups, particularly in the microfinance sector, fail. Therefore, the programme must also ensure this.
Fourthly, it must be ensured that social security benefits in member states are not discontinued for the purpose of accessing this programme; otherwise, it will be rendered ineffective.
This cannot sustainably combat unemployment.
We will reject it in this form.

Madam President, it appears to me to be somewhat symptomatic for us, that is, for the EU in general, but also for Parliament in particular, that we reflexively conduct discussions about situations in countries whose situations are not new.
It is unfortunate that very often events occurring overnight lead to a sudden, wave-like outpouring of political demands, some of which I find somewhat questionable.
I believe that it does not become us to initiate a general debate about Yemen based solely on a failed airplane attack.
I believe that we should be clear with ourselves that it would benefit us to consider a strategy for how to deal with this situation.

I also believe that the situation in Yemen requires close analysis, namely that it concerns a failed state where a government operates that no longer controls large parts of the country, and we should analyze for ourselves what risks arise from this for Europe.
The risks appear to be that terrorists are being trained there, and the risks also seem to be emerging on the coast of Yemen, where piracy is evidently taking place.
Therefore, I believe, it is up to us and perhaps also to Ms. Eschten to consider what we can do to mitigate these risks.
For my part, the answer can primarily be: how can we strengthen the government in Yemen, regain control of the country, and contain these risks.

All other discussions regarding the long-term development of the country, of course, must also be had. But I don’t believe it's really sensible, and that we will be taken seriously, if we now launch a catalogue of demands across all policy areas, from media freedom to the rights of women here in Parliament.
I believe that will not achieve the desired outcome in Yemen, but rather we should focus on what specific assistance we can offer in the current situation to resolve an acute problem. Thank you.

Thank you very much, esteemed Commissioner. Mr. President of the Council, the evaluation of passenger data is being approached in a manner similar to that of SWIFT, in an attempt to combat global terrorism and the
to reconcile serious criminal activity with the fundamental rights of each individual to the protection of privacy and also informational self-determination.

Therefore, I also consider it necessary to distinguish more precisely between the data necessary for combating crime and the data sensitive with regard to privacy.
For me, it is actually not at all a question that we must firmly integrate controls, remedies, access rights, claims for damages, and the duration of storage into the agreement.

Policy coherence for development means that we do not take with one hand what we give with the other.

It makes little sense, for example, to invest development aid in building up agriculture in developing countries while simultaneously destroying local markets through direct or indirect export subsidies.
We can advocate for better healthcare as much as we like, but if we obstruct trade in generic drugs or drive up medication prices to unaffordable levels through patent extensions.

And agrofuels may reduce CO2 emissions in the EU somewhat, but in developing countries they lead to deforestation and land conversion, and thus to increased climate change – precisely what we are currently trying to avoid. Not to mention the displacement of indigenous populations, loss of biodiversity, and reduced arable land for food production.
Currently, we—that is, the EU as such—are not particularly coherent.
That political measures should not contradict one another has been recognized by the EU in theory for some time.
The Treaty of Lisbon enshrines policy coherence for development.
Article 208 states that when implementing political measures that may affect developing countries, the Union shall take account of the objectives of development cooperation.
We must be prepared to meet this challenge.
This year, we are reviewing progress toward achieving the Millennium Development Goals.
It is clear that without political coherence, we will not succeed in fulfilling our promises.

We must become aware of this responsibility, as must all those who enact and implement laws. Before we adopt any measure, there must be an impact assessment, so that we can even recognize what aspects of European legislation could have negative effects on developing countries.
We need expertise in the council, commission, and parliament that recognizes incoherences.
The Commission’s programme of work on policy coherence is a good step in this regard,
Now it depends on how this plan is implemented.

Policy coherence for development means that in the fisheries reform, we must give greater consideration to the interests of local people and not subordinate them to the interests of European fishing conglomerates.
It means that we must dry up tax havens into which funds flow out of developing countries.
It means that we cannot agree to ACTA if the suspicion remains that this agreement could disrupt access to medicines or technologies in developing countries.
Thus far, the Commission has been unable to dispel this suspicion.

Policy coherence also means that when establishing the Foreign Service, development policy must remain a strong, independent policy area, and the Development Commissioner’s competencies must be expanded, not restricted.
And it is also important that we, for example, enable Fairtrade products in municipal procurement processes, as my colleague Heide Rühle has proposed.
In many cases, we must carefully monitor Members of the Commission and the Council to ensure that they shape policy coherently.
In many cases, it also lies with us, the members of parliament, to be coherent in the interest of development.
We need to improve coordination between the committees, and we require a permanent rapporteur.
The report, which the Development Committee unanimously adopted, makes many good suggestions and brings us a significant step forward.
I would like to thank all shadow rapporteurs, the Ombudsman, and all the NGOs for their assistance and cooperation, and I hope that our joint report can also be adopted by the full chamber tomorrow.

Madam President, esteemed colleagues, for months we have been discussing the question of driving times and working hours in road transport.
And I wonder what arguments will now be deployed to prove that everything we have been discussing for months is nonsense.
The most recent argument is that we urgently need to change something here so that nothing changes.
Do you not notice, dear Mrs. Bauer, how absurd this argumentation has become, how riddled it is with lies and half-truths?
This dispute concerns nothing other than an extension of working hours for self-employed individuals.
In labor law, the fundamental question for 150 years has been the protection of people from excessively long working hours.
This applies to both the self-employed and employees.
It is entirely irrelevant whether it is a freelancer who feels overwhelmed or an employer who overloads an employed driver.
It is about protecting people from themselves and from excessively long working hours, in part also from employers and clients.
Secondly. Regarding road traffic safety, it is asserted here that nothing could possibly happen.
Ladies and gentlemen, we are not in a hobby hardware store, nor are we amateur craftsmen. We cannot make laws on the principle of “let’s see what comes of it.”
Everyone knows that excessively long working hours create a predisposition to accidents, particularly in road traffic, with significant consequences.
Third point. Who, then, is to control such a differentiated regulation, as you envision, on our roads in the future?
It is not possible for a state labor judge to verify today whether someone appears self-employed or is self-employed without an extensive review of records.
Drop this nonsense; it concerns fair competition.
It is not about setting a priority today, tomorrow, for the future discussion regarding the extension of working hours.
Do not play such games with this house. I thank you.

Thank you, Madam President. As I have been doing for many years now, today I am committed to road safety, an improvement in the working conditions of our professional drivers, and the enhancement of their professional image.

Clearly, today we are not addressing the traffic safety-relevant regulations concerning driving and rest times that all self-employed and employed professional drivers must adhere to. Today, we are addressing working time regulations.
It is primarily a regulation to protect employees, and therefore serves solely the social protection of drivers and in no way traffic safety.
We do not need to protect the self-employed from themselves.

Compliance with working hours is neither controllable with significant bureaucratic effort in the case of self-employed truck and bus drivers, nor is there a traceable reason why it should be controlled at all.

Restricting self-employed professional drivers, and potentially in the future also self-employed tradespeople, architects, or elected officials, in their permissible working hours sends the wrong signal.
