The Cohesion Fund places a disproportionate burden and excessively relieves the Member States that are particularly challenged in ensuring a sustainable future for transport.
And we have just established a special committee in Parliament to debate what the future of the European Union’s cohesion and structural funds will look like. Its work should not be prioritized.
Therefore, I also request your approval of the proposed amendment to the report.
And furthermore, I believe that when we discuss sustainability and the future of transportation systems, magnetic levitation technology should also be given a future and an opportunity. Thank you.
Madam President, my esteemed colleagues, ladies and gentlemen, we have a common internal market, but fragmented oversight.
It is obvious that this cannot function.
We need strong, central European structures that utilize the expertise and detailed knowledge of the member states’ bodies, but also possess the power to intervene in emergencies.
I believe the citizen, given the enormous tax burden imposed by this crisis, expects prompt, swift, and well-founded decisions to be made here.
Citizens are little concerned when power plays are enacted at the national level, where the sole issue is who decides.
What the citizen wants is for decisions to be made effectively, for problems to be solved.

It is objectively the case that in emergency situations concerning measures, these must be centrally regulated and decided at the European level when coordination between member states is insufficient and does not function.
That does not align with the decisions of the G20, the G8, and the heads of state and government—unfortunately not at the level of the Council.
The wheel makes him small, small, a small checkboard pattern.
This is not an acceptable policy for citizens.
We expect the Council to take action. Thank you.

Gentlemen Commissioners, dear colleagues, one occasionally wonders what we have actually been doing for over a year now with discussions and debates, with many sessions in the trilogue, where I could certainly have envisioned something more pleasant than spending time there.

And we stand, more than a year after the European elections, where we proclaimed on the streets and squares how we intended to tame the financial markets, essentially before a very meager to non-existent result.
The problem has already been described.
We are dealing with markets that operate globally today.
And the member states still believe that they are capable of enforcing the rules of the game with their national supervisory structures.
And precisely that it didn't function in that way also contributed, not triggering the financial crisis, but contributing to the fact that it also affected Europe.

Therefore, the question arises for me as to when this realization, frequently articulated in Sunday speeches, will also be translated into political action, where suddenly it is about protecting stock exchange locations, where it is about protecting banking structures, and no longer about protecting citizens.

As the European Parliament, we have dedicated ourselves to this task, and I hope that the Member States will also dedicate themselves to it, because they share responsibility for implementing proper supervisory rules for the citizens, ensuring that each individual’s savings remain permanently secure.

And naturally, gentlemen commissioners, I should wish that the Commission now truly does everything possible to ensure that we arrive at a good result as quickly as possible, in the interest of the people of Europe.
Dear colleagues, we stand in this European Parliament with the responsibility for strong regulation of the financial markets.
All of what we proposed has been significantly diluted in the trilogues.
The government and administration do not desire extensive interventionist powers.
Giegold is right to describe what is currently happening as parochial thinking.
Not to curtail regulation, but rather to construct the system somewhat more fault-free, appears to be the intention.
We will end up with a fragmented supervisory structure that will be unable to exercise genuine control over financial markets.
From this financial crisis, from this economic crisis, insufficient consequences are drawn, thereby preparing the next crisis.
Many national economies, even in Europe, will not withstand the next shocks, with all the social and economic consequences for the people of Europe.
They expect this predatory financial market capitalism to be recaptured and the primacy of politics restored.
When the CEO of UniCredit Bank, Alessandro Profumo, stated at the weekend that we need a strong and uniform European financial supervision and a common rule for all member states,
Member states, and he advocates for stricter capital regulations; then this is an appeal to this Parliament to truly establish these rules.
It is the responsibility of this European Parliament to exert pressure on the Council to urgently implement effective regulation. This would be merely the first step towards a status quo ante.
Let concrete actions follow these bold promises at last. My group stands for robust European regulation.
Anything else, a lack of regulation, would be a danger to the euro, to a common EU, and to democracy. Thank you.
Thank you, Mr. President, unfortunate timing for this statement.
I would have liked to see the Dutch team win, even if it were the last time in this World Cup.
Probably a bad omen, because we’re no longer allowed to watch now, and then they probably won’t win after all.

But getting back to the matter, Commissioner, yes, you are giving the correct signal. Commissioner, Mr. President, we will finalize a legislative package today or tomorrow, to be precise, that we have been discussing for more than two years.
This is not only due to the controversy, but also to an intervening European election and also a showdown involving a new EU treaty, which has led to the need to adjust certain matters.

But I believe that if we draw a conclusion from this debate today, I come to the conclusion that we should now vote on a compromise, one that is certainly worth saying yes to, even if one might perhaps do so with a clenched fist in one’s pocket.
I would like to highlight two aspects.
That concerns the environmental requirements for industrial facilities.
The objective here is to ensure that the best available technology in Europe is more effectively implemented.
I believe that we have found an exception clause in the current compromise that gives the European Commission—Mr. Botocznik, and this is quite clear and directed at you—the instrument to use in the

in the coming years to pay even greater and better attention to ensuring that the approximately 52,000 industrial facilities affected in Europe ultimately utilize best available techniques more effectively than they do today.
I have heard many arguments in this debate.
I would like to address one point and reflect it here, because I simply cannot comprehend it.
I have often been told that the use of best available technology is too expensive and that it endangers the competitiveness of European industry, especially during a crisis.
I do not like to recall my past, but I am from the former GDR, from East Germany.
The economic and ecological collapse of the GDR was also attributable to having missed decades of investment in the latest technology in recent years.

And I believe that every industry, every industrial enterprise, is obligated by virtue of its existence to invest in the latest state of the technology, because otherwise it loses competitiveness and, incidentally, also reduces pollutant emissions.
I believe we have today the opportunity to enact a law that improves this initial situation.
The second part of the directive, and this is something of a concentrated fist, as I mentioned, concerns large combustion plants.

We are once again discussing – as we already did in the previous directive – renewed exemptions until 2020, in some cases until 2023, for large combustion plants that do not have to meet environmental requirements, particularly air pollutant emission limits.
I am addressing this message to the council, perhaps also a little to all of us, that we need to very carefully consider just how sensible it actually is that we regularly
Ambitious environmental goals are welcomed and discussed here, and we gladly receive them. But whenever it comes to implementing them, to drafting concrete legislation, a tragedy begins in Europe.
Then the member states suddenly realize what it costs, which bills they have to pay, and typically those who have made prior commitments are penalized as a result.
There is, in fact, a number of member states that already meet the requirements today and which will ultimately be left standing in the rain.
And I say it again here, both with industrial plants and large combustion plants, they are essentially coal-fired power plants. Let's not talk about science fiction.
We are not discussing things that are not available, but rather it is the latest state of the art.
Best Available Techniques, that which is available on the market under competitive and cost-related aspects, can be incorporated into these facilities. And against this backdrop, we conclude today.
today a package of legislation, which I believe is better than what is currently in effect, and for that reason I encourage us all to approve it.

And I also thank my colleagues, some of whom have been involved over the past two years with considerable rigor, for their support, for their contributions, and above all, for the fact that almost all key parliamentary groups have co-signed this compromise. Thank you.
Thank you, Mr. President. Three things have happened while we have been debating. Firstly, it is clear that Europe will become football world champion.
A good omen, I believe.
Whether that will be the case, we shall see.
I do not wish to express any preferences at this time.
Secondly, Germany is receiving compliments from the UK.
Chris Davis, many thanks. It doesn't happen every day.
It is worth noting that.
And thirdly, the world is still in order; even among the Greens, football is more important than environmental protection.
Unfortunately, our colleague Bas Aykut has already left again.
But heartfelt congratulations, of course, to our Dutch friends.
I wished to raise two aspects in the debate, which has just concluded.
Firstly, I understand all the concerns and hardships of my Eastern European friends only too well.
I, as someone from East Germany, am also, in a way, half Eastern European.
And I understand that not every environmental policy step undertaken in Western European countries in recent decades can now be immediately replicated in Eastern Europe.
Environmental protection at a high level must be affordable.
Yes, that is correct.

But I believe that even taking this sentence into account, it is worthwhile to agree to this compromise, because it does justice to the diverse starting situations in which many member states find themselves.
And secondly, the argument that the use of best available techniques jeopardizes competitiveness, particularly in relation to China. This argument is not only false, it is even dangerous.
We must confront the fact that industrial processes in Asia are definitely cheaper than they are here.
And we will only succeed in this competition if we implement the best available technology in as many industrial sectors as possible.
Whoever fails to do so loses competitiveness.
No one demands, not even this law, that an industrial operation be shut down tomorrow.
No one demands an immediate jump from 0 to 100 to achieve any pollutant limit within a week.
We have sufficient transition periods. But to say that one should forgo them for competitive reasons is incorrect.

And I believe that with this directive, we have not only set an environmental policy course, but I also believe we have made a significant industrial policy decision. It would be worthwhile to work on this in the coming years. Thank you very much.

Thank you, Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen. I would like to begin by first expressing my gratitude to my colleagues from the other groups who assisted in the preparation of my report on Kosovo, including Ms. Eva Mahr, who provided very valuable support in the secretariat.

And to you, Mr. Commissioner, I would also like to express my thanks for the good cooperation, but also, as you mentioned, that it was important to you to travel to the north of Kosovo, to even spend a night there, and thereby make it clear to the population that you stand for that population as well.
You delivered a speech at the university and inaugurated the EU House there.

I believe that was an important signal to make clear what this European Parliament has already expressed in the past and is expressing again now, namely its support for an independent Kosovo on its path to the European Union.
We are currently facing a situation where Kosovo, for its citizens – particularly those of all ethnic groups – is once again at a critical juncture.
In a few weeks, the International Court of Justice will deliver its opinion on the position regarding the declaration of independence from just over two years ago.

I hope that this decision, this opinion will be an opportunity—something like an open window, as it is called in English—to establish regional cooperation on a new basis, but without relinquishing national sovereignty.

originating from Kosovo and based on its independence. And to make clear that the shared future for all states in the region, for Serbia, for Kosovo and all others, lies in membership of the European Union, and that on the path towards that goal, the problems that still exist must also be resolved.
It is also the text of a resolution that makes it clear the future of Kosovo lies in the European Union.

I am pleased that we have a majority that also urges the five member states that have not yet recognized [something] to do so soon. That the Commission is also once again urged to begin visa liberalization as soon as possible.

for the citizens of the country, especially the young, must not have the impression that they live in an isolated state, that they cannot go out, while everyone else in the surrounding area will soon have that future.
I believe that is the task.
I hope to find a large majority in the plenary session tomorrow as well.

I have also submitted a new amendment proposal that prioritizes strong regret over the outbreaks of violence of the past few days and expresses great hope for swift and independent clarification, without allowing this to serve as a basis for escalating emotions in the coming days and weeks. Thank you.
Madam President, distinguished representatives, esteemed Commissioner, dear colleagues, the most appalling events in Kyrgyzstan, the outbreaks of violence, the slaughter of people, the
The burning of houses and the streams of tens of thousands of refugees who abandoned their homes and attempted to flee the violence – all of this shook me and evoked compassion for the victims.
Simultaneously, these events in Kyrgyzstan also shed light on the situation in Central Asia, which must not leave us unaffected here in the European Parliament.
Conversely, we should devote our full attention to the countries of this region.

In doing so, we should not only focus on the states rich in resources and of particular economic interest to us in Europe, but also consider all states equally within the framework of the Central Asia Strategy adopted in 2007.
That, I believe, is our obligation.
The Central Asian states, which gained independence less than 20 years ago from what was once Tsarist and later Soviet rule, bear a heavy legacy.

Boundaries arbitrarily drawn by Stalin, with no regard for the ancestral homelands of the populations residing there, evidently complicate coexistence both within and beyond the borders of these states.
Poverty, corruption, disregard for human and minority rights, authoritarian regimes, economic conditions—as exemplified in Tajikistan and Kyrgyzstan, hundreds of thousands,
Labor migration forces, and as is now being acknowledged in Kyrgyzstan, allow conflict resolution through the application of violence, leaving the future trajectory of these states uncertain.
Here, we must not, the European Union must not merely stand by.

If we do not want to allow the path of these states to be led into fundamentalist structures, if we do not want to leave people there permanently at the mercy of dictatorial regimes, it requires our full commitment.
Alongside the urgently needed material assistance, we need contact with these states, and active support for the democratic forces developing there.
Let us give Minister President Rosa Otunbayeva a chance in pacifying Kyrgyzstan and on the path toward stable political conditions. Let us allow for the debate today and the vote tomorrow.

Resolution must be followed by action, so that the people of Kyrgyzstan and the other Central Asian states feel that we will not abandon them on their path to the future, nor will we hand them over to undemocratic forces.
The expectations of people in these countries are high. We should not disappoint them. Thank you very much.
The report was based on four grounds.
The architecture of the service has numerous weaknesses, the subtleties of which will continue to cause us considerable concern.
The second point is that the European ambassador will manage commission funds in the future.
This exposes the funds to a variety of risks, and the safeguards for these risks remain, as yet, entirely unclear.
The third point concerns the role of the Members of this Parliament in a Council Regulation.
We are, in this process, de facto co-decision makers, yet we have allowed a Council regulation to preempt parliamentary rights.
Therefore, I would like to state, for my dossier, regarding the rules of procedure, that I do not consider myself bound by today’s decisions.
The fourth point concerns how we actually interact with each other in Parliament.
We approved a parliamentary reform in the last period and procedures that we are now all disregarding, with the agreement of the Presidium and with the agreement of the President.
Why are we undertaking a parliamentary reform that prescribes procedures when, at crucial moments, we already violate them and do not adhere to them?

For these reasons, I cannot agree with this report.

Sincerely.
Thank you, Mr. President. Commissioner, I am very much in favor of genetic engineering, but cloning, that is something else.
That cannot be compared to it at all.
Cloning is animal cruelty. And many colleagues have already stated that here.
I also presented this during the discussion we had before the summer break. Only a fraction of animal clones is actually viable.
And those who survive, a very, very large number of them die very early, and often in great suffering.
You are suffering from malformations of extremities, of organs.
They have weakened immune systems; they are susceptible to illness.
That means pain and suffering, and precisely that agonizing death.
Can we possibly be responsible for that?
We advocate for animal welfare and then want to support such technology.
No, that is not what we want, and that is why we decided in July that we do not want any cloned meat or animal products from cloned animals.
And that is only consistent.

Yes, we know that products from cloned animals or their descendants are unlikely to be harmful to health, and I personally believe that they would actually be suitable for human consumption. But there is, in fact, no shortage of meat from conventionally raised animals.
Why should we engage in cloning?
It is, after all, entirely unnecessary to engage in this animal cruelty. And the population simply does not want it.
The population does not want these products. We do not need them ourselves either. There is no argument for cloned meat in the European Union.
And therefore, we want to establish a very clear regulation explicitly for cloned animals and, yes, also for their progeny.
I want a ban on cloning and cloned products within the European Union. And I also believe that we can enforce this.
Naturally, this must also apply to imports.
And I want to be certain that I’m not surreptitiously served cloned meat, because it’s not labeled, as has already happened here in Germany.
And I do not believe that all meat can be traced.
With beef, this may be possible.
However, with pork, due to the sheer volume produced, it will not be possible to trace back whether an animal ever had a clone in its ancestry.
Fundamentally, yes, it is a matter of principle, it is an ethical question.
And other colleagues have said it too – we must also address ethical questions, and we are responsible for ethical questions as well.
And of course, there is the question of animal welfare, but it is also another question.
Experience shows – I am an animal producer, I have studied it – that all reproductive techniques, once they truly functioned in animal production, were ultimately also applied to humans.
And we must, therefore, ask ourselves today: do we want and can we accept cloning technology in the not-so-distant future? Can we do so even with humans?
I do not want that, and I cannot do that either.
And even if a replacement part clone could perhaps one day donate a vital organ to me, a clone of myself, then I would not want that.
And I don't believe that to be an exaggerated horror vision.
I believe that it simply would not be all too fair to make that possible in the future, if we were to permit cloning.
And therefore, we urgently need a ban not only on cloning, but also on cloned animals and their offspring throughout the entire EU.
And I have no fear of the WTO.
We can enforce that.
We do not need to emulate everything the United States demonstrates to us, despite all trans-Atlantic friendship. Thank you.

Dear colleagues,

It is no coincidence that we find it so difficult to reach an agreement here, as two irreconcilable subjects are being conflated.
We likely would have found common ground regarding trademark protection had we focused on it.
But the conflation with the matter of the Internet is also factually incorrect, because it requires new, different strategies here than in material law.
That cannot be simply transferred.
Furthermore, one must be clear about the fact that we pay for every prosecution in the digital sphere with infringements on civil rights, because one cannot simply see or determine this on one's own.
And the third point is really clear to me. If I already place cultural enjoyment online under the threat of penalties, so that I am practically always standing with one foot in the
If I am in prison, then if I look into the web, I will not be able to utilize the opportunities that the internet also offers for art, culture, and creativity.
Therefore, my appeal is to continue discussing this. That would be clear.
Thank you very much.
Mr. Chairman, property, whether it be intellectual or physical property, is a cornerstone of a market economy.
And therefore, I believe it is important that we consider how we can regulate this issue together through good consensus.
We absolutely need a warning signal.
Stop-Shop. It must become simpler for consumers, for the self-employed, and for small and medium-sized enterprises to obtain the corresponding licenses.
Precisely the availability of licenses for intellectual property rights applicable throughout the EU is of particular importance.
We need an internal market for intellectual property.
We need, above all, the original language to be available throughout Europe.
Every language is an important cultural asset, and it should be possible to grant licenses for a language that are valid throughout Europe and therefore usable by all citizens.
We require interoperability and technical neutrality in order to utilize this intellectual property accordingly.
And we need, above all, sanctions for those who violate competition and trade law.
Dear colleagues, I have taken note that the Council does not wish to discuss the multiannual financial framework.

I would like to inform this Council that the European Parliament is already keen to discuss this matter, and that the Council cannot behave like a kindergarten and say that it will not answer our questions or our proposals.
Secondly, I must ask the Council, in this context, whether it wants Lisbon or whether it does not want Lisbon.
Lisbon is not a purely technical alteration, but signifies more tasks, means more task completion, and consequently answering related financial questions.
Furthermore, the Council adopted resolutions that will result in new financial expenditures.
This has been carried out by many colleagues.

If the council desires this and if the council desires that no more money should be spent, then the council must also state where it specifically wishes to make savings, how it wishes to make savings, where it wishes to reallocate funds precisely, and not merely in general terms.

to suggest percentage shifts and then leave it to the Parliament and the Commission to decide where the inconveniences fall, particularly as the possibilities for reallocations and changes to the budget are extremely limited for us.

The tasks that they additionally assigned to us are so challenging that they do not involve minor, peripheral matters, but I will mention alone the areas of financial stability of our states and their corresponding financial difficulties.
And when the program needs to be utilized, then these are not insignificant sums that one could simply redirect ad hoc.

The same applies to ITER, the same applies to questions of internal security, the same applies to major research issues, and the same also applies to questions when I address areas of focus that the Parliament has, namely in the field of youth education and research.
We are partly dealing with a lack of implementation. We are also partly dealing with a lack of transparency in the allocation of funds.
All these questions must be addressed and processed concretely together, and not answered through silence on the part of the Council.
Dear Commissioner Hahn, colleagues, I have a problem with parts of the debate.
When we speak of mountains, islands, and sparsely populated regions, I get the impression from individual contributions that they are extraterritorial and directly subordinate to the European Union.
But that is not the case.
Each of these areas belongs to a member state, which are sovereign.
And the implementation of European resolutions and objectives remains, in accordance with the principle of subsidiarity, the responsibility of the Member States.

When I consider the European level, we have consistently focused particularly on these regions—mountainous areas, sparsely populated areas, islands—in Commission communications up to the Lisbon Treaty.
And here, too, in Parliament, many resolutions were passed to support this region.
When I hear so many complaints here now that problems persist in these regions, the question arises for me: how have the member states dealt with the impetus we sent from the European level?
And how did the regions themselves approach this and utilize European funding opportunities?

Here, a new strategy is being demanded. I already feel sorry for the officials at DG Regio who are tasked with incorporating the multitude of problems facing islands, mountains, and sparsely populated areas into a strategy.

Simultaneously, we are experiencing an inflation of strategies—Danube, Baltic Sea, Black Sea, climate change, and the like—to the point where we will soon need a strategy for the strategies, so that we can still maintain an overview.

Esteemed colleagues, joking aside. I believe what it’s really about, and this has also been mentioned today, and for that I am very grateful to Commissioner Hahn for bringing it up. We must fight to ensure that there is also a coalition policy and a regional policy at the European level after 2013.
That, I believe, is the focus of our work, and that is also where we should convince our colleagues in parliament that this will be the case.
And in a continuation of coalition and regional policy extending beyond the year 2013, mountains, islands, and the other territories will also find their place.
However, we should not become sidetracked with individual motions regarding the topic, for which there is currently no occasion. Thank you very much.
Mr. President, dear colleagues, first of all, my thanks to the colleagues who have worked so intensely on this project, in particular to colleague Bilal Quadras.
This is proof that European policy is capable of responding to crises and offering solutions that provide assistance.
We have experienced these supply security situations repeatedly.
The problem of supply security has thus become clearer and more distinct.
We were compelled to act, and we have acted.

We have found solutions that were not simple, that also mean new instruments, and what I find interesting about them is that they do not merely create infrastructure standards in Europe, do not merely establish common rules for prevention and emergency plans, do not merely provide the certainty that the Commissioner rightly

has demonstrated not only that we can offer people 30 days of security in the future, but also that we are capable of exploring compromises. Compromises that can then lead to actionable solutions. That was

off track, but it is now becoming clear that both the role and the responsibility of the companies involved—those who build the networks and are responsible for them—as well as the flexibility of politics, which says we will not force things that ultimately prove uneconomical or unwise, are central.

are no longer reasonable. This includes, for example, flexibility in backflows, in necessary backflows, but not to say in all cases, always, and at any price, but also the necessity or possibility of being able to assess individual cases, as well as strengthening cooperation in the regional sphere and

And equally important, I believe, is the point that Member States must also assume their responsibilities. But if solutions cannot be found there, then the Commission receives an additional task. The Commission, which is strengthened, but which does not decide alone, but decides when other solutions are no longer possible, or has the final say.
Also flexibility, solutions that keep the burdens within manageable limits, but last but not least, ensure that solutions exist. And that is the good news from Brussels for the people of Europe.
Mr. President, dear colleagues, my most esteemed Commissioners, I need not emphasize how vital cohesion policy and regional policy are to the harmonious coexistence and integration within Europe.
However, I also believe that the regional and cohesion policies of the future must increasingly focus on cities.
For cities are an important engine in Europe's development.
Simultaneously, however, you are currently experiencing ecological, economic, and social problems in a particularly acute manner.
Therefore, my very specific question to Commissioner Hahn. What possibilities do you see for highlighting the urban dimensions?

Specifically, Mr. Commissioner, you recently suggested at an event here at our institution that you could envision a particular percentage being reserved from the regional funds, precisely to emphasize the urban dimension.
Are these considerations still relevant?
If so, what percentage could this potentially be?

Thank you, Mr. Chairman. First, I would like to thank Commissioner Hahn for initiating a new debate here, as a former Minister for Economic Affairs and Innovation, a debate which, I believe, can make a significant contribution to growth in Europe.
If every small and medium-sized enterprise in Europe were to create one additional job, we would have no unemployment in Europe any longer.
Therefore, we should consider how we can empower small and medium-sized enterprises in particular to take on new employees and, accordingly, become active in international export markets.
But research infrastructure is also a significant concern, just as is infrastructure in the transport sector.
Here, the Commission, I believe, has significant tasks ahead of it, particularly restructuring the East-West connection, for example, Paris-Budapest or North-South.
Here, additional jobs can be created, which we urgently need in Europe at present.

Madam President, esteemed colleagues, it is undeniable that we have made progress in gender equality in recent years. Nevertheless, there are still many women who are relegated to low-skilled employment.
This applies not only to activities traditionally performed within the family.
In the deregulation of recent years, compulsory health insurance employment has frequently been transformed into atypical, precarious, and insecure working conditions.
there, especially women.
The Euro-Kalevikian employment development from 2000 to 2010 comprises 60% new, precarious, and atypical employment relationships, predominantly two-thirds of which are held by women.
Frequently, women are denied democratic participation through their part-time employment or precarious employment in businesses.
Women are, however, considerably more engaged and better educated than in all previous generations.
You still earn 25 percent less than men on average.

We in the Employment Committee have engaged with this topic very intensively and developed good proposals for the question of female employment. The inclusion, regardless of the status of their work, in

social security systems, the establishment of childcare facilities, the alignment of pensions and social systems with independent living, and the design of work according to the principles of decent work.
All of this essentially concerns the precarious employment of women as addressed in the report.
The Employment Committee is satisfied with the outcome of this work and requests approval for the submitted report. Thank you.
Yes, thank you, Madam Chair. Mr. President of the Council, landmines will likely continue to represent a significant problem for the foreseeable future.
Do you believe it is possible to initiate one’s own research programs for the detection of landmines?
That is not merely a European problem; it is a global problem.
And can you envision identifying suitable institutions here that engage with research programs in this field?

My colleagues, in transatlantic dialogue, there is always much that unites us. These are fundamental values, fundamental rights of freedom and democracy. However, there are also differences, namely in the application and concretization of these respective rights when it comes to transatlantic relations.
Especially when it comes to security issues, this contradiction becomes strikingly apparent.
Data protection is a source of constant misunderstandings. We have known this for a long time.
Therefore, the framework agreement, should we succeed in obtaining a very good one, will be a significant step forward.
We must find a solution here that enables citizens on both sides of the Atlantic to assert their rights with the other partner.
A second important point where we have similar fundamentals but very different approaches is climate protection.
Therefore, I greatly wish that it becomes a topic and that it is discussed clearly.
The European Union must not use the transatlantic dialogue to weaken its own promises and commitments. Thank you.
For investment fund managers, there is now, for the first time, a degree of transparency and regulation in this opaque jungle of hedge funds and alternative investment funds.
Unfortunately, these rules remained incomplete.
It remains possible to access the common market with unregulated products within the scope of passive distribution.
Essentially, market access for these products is not effectively restricted.
Europe has thus missed an opportunity to expand its rules internationally and to achieve a unified regulation.
Secondly, unfortunately, unlike what Parliament intended, there was no effective debt brake at the European level for the funds.
National regulations alone continue to determine the extent to which fund debt can be limited. And that means that the consequences of the crisis are not being addressed here.
There will be a national race to the bottom in regulation.
It is crucial for us to reiterate that the plundering of companies by private equity funds must also be effectively prevented.
Of course, there are Private Equity investments that are sensible for companies,
But the rules now being implemented are, unfortunately, far from sufficient.
Also ineffective are the information rights of employees, whom they rightfully expect, as well as the protection of small and medium-sized enterprises from this form of exploitation.
Therefore, it is very difficult to justify this vis-à-vis the voters.

Unfortunately, it is the case that the responsibility does not lie with Parliament; it lies particularly with intensive lobbying efforts by the relevant industry, successful primarily with the British government.

Government, with the French government, but I must unfortunately say also, to some extent, with the German government, and we had representation of these lobbyists here in Parliament primarily in the form of the liberal faction.
We cannot agree with this proposal, as it would set a precedent for the parliament failing to enforce effective rules.
It is not possible for us to stand before our voters with pride and say that we have succeeded in effectively regulating this shadow realm.
We hope that we will be able to make further progress during the revision of the guideline.
Many thanks again, and above all for the collaboration here with my colleagues in Parliament.
Yes, thank you very much. Also, my sincere thanks initially to colleague Walz for the collaboration.
I can only emphasize this, even with differing positions, it has been a good collaboration.
Many—I want to emphasize this again—many believed that the crisis of the Eurozone had been over.
Ireland demonstrates that this was not the case.
Europe continues to voluntarily surrender itself to financial markets.
The member states of the EU must continue to hawk their sovereign debt on the bazaar of financial markets and acquire the confidence of speculators through austerity.
Over the weekend, we once again had to observe where that leads.

This time, it was not the Greeks, supposedly prone to fraud, but the model student Ireland that was driven into the European rescue funds to save its banking system, which for a long time was also considered exemplary, as being exemplarily deregulated.
Meanwhile, the financial sector is already eyeing Portugal’s capitalization, as its interest rates continue to rise.
The ECB bears a share of responsibility for this drama.
She failed to seize the opportunity and failed to further offer a civilized alternative to the state casino by issuing Eurobonds.
While one half of Europe is recovering from the crisis, the ECB watches impassively as the other half continues to sink further into poverty and insecurity.
The collapse of entire national economies may, according to the taste of European fund and banking crises, have helped neither Ireland nor the monetary union nor the ECB.
Mr. Trichet, please do not disregard Frau Merkel’s plain-language financial primer.
If you want to save the Economic and Monetary Union, do not let European sovereign bonds hang in the air.
Introduce Eurobonds before the next speculation victim falls.

Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, considering how we discussed this Commission proposal in the previous legislative term—from total rejection to enthusiastic praise of all the good things to come—I must say I am delighted with what is presented here now.
And a great deal of thanks is due to the rapporteur and their co-rapporteurs for having crafted a coherent opinion from this broad spectrum of views.
I believe the magic word for that lies in patient-centeredness.
Therefore, one did not consider the many side effects, but stated what the patient needs.
I believe it is correct that we have decided that the patient can become informed in various ways, and not just one.
But I would like to emphasize that the physician will continue to be the patient’s trusted point of contact and will also certainly exert influence in critical matters.
We guarantee this, because we have, in fact, prohibited advertising for it, and the information the patient receives has been verified and approved by an authority.
This ensures that the information is initially supported by scientific evidence, allowing the patient to confidently engage with it.
Naturally, it is correct; not everyone can determine this.
We obtain it via the internet. We have various ways of doing so, and I believe that, given its widespread nature, we don’t need to worry about it.
I only hope that the council now finally has the courage to address this topic.
It is very important; it must be acted upon quickly.
The patients expect that.
I believe that we have accomplished a good piece of work. Thank you very much.
Madam President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, dear colleagues, coal is part of the energy supply – that is indisputable.
It is also undisputed that competitiveness must be ensured and that subsidization may not be the correct approach.
The question now is whether the date of 2014 or 2018 is the correct one.
My colleague Rabka has presented a great many astute arguments that I need not repeat.
And my request to the Commission is essentially only this: there is obviously a large majority in Parliament, in all the committees involved, to affirm that competitiveness must be a criterion.

But that we establish the necessary flexibility in the matter of the timeline, which is essential to ensure that the Member States can actually implement it and that the burdens on people, on jobs, and on economic structures remain manageable.

The sole argument that has been mentioned, which, incidentally, also contradicted the Commission’s impact assessment, which initially seemed inclined to express itself regarding 2018, was the argument that climate policy considerations may play a role here.
I want to emphasize the point again. It makes no difference to the question of climate whether one burns foreign coal or one's own coal.

And my request to the Commissioner is to reflect once again on whether this four-year period, when presented to Parliament and if such a new line of argumentation arises in the Council, could not lead to the Commission also becoming somewhat more flexible.
I understood the comment just now to mean that the commission is considering this, and I thank you for that.

Mr. President, Madam Minister, Madam Commissioner, if one is to draw a lesson from Copenhagen, where you, Madam Commissioner, held the presidency, then it is that the European Union must speak with one voice in future conferences.

We may well differ in opinion at one point or another here. But if, as Europeans, we already speak with divergent voices, then our weight will not be credible. And if we are not credible, then other people will not follow us.
Why should they?
Therefore, I believe it is correct that the figures we decided on at the end of 2007 under Chancellor Merkel must essentially remain valid and form the foundations of these negotiations.

I share your opinion that the ambitious 2-degree target should not be seriously questioned today in favor of a significantly lower degree, because doing so would make achieving these targets extraordinarily difficult and would drive people away from them.
I have a significant concern that we are jeopardizing our intellectual property.
Also, our industry invests money and manpower to develop things.
If we were to go in now and loosen the fence around this intellectual property and leave the holes as they are, then the valuable parts, namely our property, would simply walk away.
I am certainly in favor of technology transfer, but our companies must also see a point in investing in it. And therefore, intellectual property must not be improved.
as far as obligations are concerned. Also, I am inclined to require serious commitments from our partners worldwide.
but they must be credible and they must be feasible for these countries.
Otherwise, we do precisely the opposite of what we want, namely, they will distance themselves from us.

The major decisions will be made later in Johannesburg. But in Cancun, I believe, we should prepare the ground.
I am a farmer by profession.
If the field is not in good order, there will be nothing with the harvest.
Let us focus on the good soil.
Thank you, Mr. President. Mr. President, an incident occurred during the debate on the European Council this morning to which I no longer wish to refer myself, as I was the target of an insult.
However, I want to say that there are levels at which I cannot be offended and where I do not perceive something as an insult, because to insult me, one must possess a certain degree of earnestness.
I would, however, like to express my sincere gratitude for the countless expressions of solidarity I have received here in this building since then.
I would like to sincerely thank you, dear colleagues from all factions.
I believe this is a sign of our collective, democratic, and pro-European conviction, which is shared by the overwhelming majority of this House.
For this, my sincere thanks.

Dear Commissioner, dear Minister, dear Mr. Gosses, and esteemed colleagues and shadow rapporteurs, first and foremost, I am pleased that we have now created this opportunity, that for the first time a sector of the European financial system is placed under European direct oversight.
This is also a step towards a strong Europe within a single market, for strong control over a sector that has contributed to the crisis.
Allow me to add a remark, dear Mr. Barnier. The selection processes for the new authorities are currently underway, and those authorities will only be as good as their personnel.

And I can only hope that in the selection of personnel, the focus will truly be on expertise, on independence from the financial industry they are meant to control, and on a clear commitment to public interests, and that we will not see national quotas again in the selection process that supersede these important criteria.
Furthermore, much remains to be done in the area of rating agencies.

We still lack proper transparency regarding the information used by rating agencies. There is far too much reliance on regulatory ratings within the financial sector and in regulations governing the financial industry.
We have severe conflicts of interest, we clearly have a market power held by three major providers, and we accept no liability for negligently created ratings.
Therefore, I ask you, Mr. Commissioner, it is good that the consultation is now underway, and we are keen to see the results.
And I also believe that civil society should participate in this consultation. But then it must also be about making a bold proposal.
I look forward to receiving your proposal.
Let us be as courageous as we have been thus far, and let us together legislate next year to truly resolve, in a European manner, the problems that still exist in the ratings market.
This is what we owe to the citizens.
Yes, thank you, Mr. President, Mr. Minister, Mr. Barnier, and colleagues. The damage that rating agencies can inflict has been demonstrated by the past few months since the beginning of this year.
Therefore, there is an urgent need for action.

And therefore, I welcome the directive—or, to that extent, I also welcome the directive—particularly, I welcome the fact that the European Securities and Markets Authority (ESMA) would be entrusted with the supervision and registration of credit rating agencies.
I believe this is an important and positive step forward.
However, numerous good and progressive proposals were lost during the negotiations on the report.
And I would like to reiterate that here.
The designation of ESMA, therefore, remains the sole genuine and positive innovation.
The proposals for a public data base for the creation of ratings have been dropped. Likewise, there is no mention of the establishment of a public rating agency.
Even the consistent and continuous review of created ratings by supervisory authorities has fallen by the wayside.

The Commission had also continued to propose funding for independent ratings in order to overcome detrimental issuer instructions for the assessment of financial market products. Nothing of that has remained either.
I hope that these aspects will be taken into consideration in the reports still to come on this topic by Jean-Paul Groset and also by you, Mr. Barnier. Thank you.
Mr. Chairman, Commissioner, dear colleagues, dear colleagues, first of all, my thanks to those who worked on this report, in particular to Colleague Benzen.
I would like to draw attention to two points and perhaps provoke a little reflection.
We agree that energy efficiency, the economical use of energy, is the solution. The simplest and most reasonable one.
The question is, how do we achieve this goal?
And I would like to ask the question, what has it actually achieved, that we in Parliament have repeatedly approached the people with new and higher percentages.
Have we truly achieved more and accomplished more?
Or why, and in what locations, has energy been handled more sparingly?
that energy-intensive industries handle energy more efficiently because it saves them money and because it is advantageous for them.

And I am learning that people, when they know this device consumes more energy or less energy – so when they see it and can decide for themselves that there is an advantage – then they will choose it.
perhaps the method isn't really about working with percentages, but rather about proceeding correctly through incentives.
Second question. The Commissioner has just presented, in a very impressive and clear manner, how complicated the description of the term “What is that actually?” is in itself.
How differently is this implemented in the member states?
The colleague has just pointed out that the member states also have very different situations, economically, geographically, totally different.
Is it then the right answer to work with a number, with a binding number, or must something else not occur to us?

I believe we must, in energy policy, distance ourselves somewhat from the debates of the past, which, with simplistic figures, binding targets, and seemingly miraculous solutions, aim to achieve something. Because it is obvious that we have not achieved enough.

Perhaps we should try a different approach once, a differentiated one, one that accommodates diverse responses, that takes into account the different situations, sensitivities, but also achieves impact.
It depends on the effects. It does not depend on our state of being.
This regulation, which is being discussed today, has long received little attention in all the committees.
Now, at the end, when the result was available, some people in this institution were awakened.
Some are unfortunately not present for the debate today. It would have been very, very interesting to hear your opinions as well.
As a former member of the Convent, the spirit of the Convent remains vividly clear to me.
has clearly demanded in many areas that the European Parliament must receive specific rights in order to maintain its credibility both within the institutions and vis-à-vis citizens.
Consequently, what the chapter had presented to us was still not a given.
These were extremely difficult negotiations, particularly led by the Belgian presidency vis-à-vis the Council, which have enabled some important progress to be made.
I recall what my colleague Lehne already said; that was precisely the question of the constant possibility of verifying whether the Commission had exceeded its powers.
Naturally, there are some arrangements that are not entirely ideal, such as international trade agreements, but nevertheless I can declare myself in agreement with the outcome.

She truly exerted herself to ensure something would happen and our correspondent, who negotiated with heart and mind.
13, I would like to make the following statement on behalf of our group. This is a proposal that my colleague Göran Färm put forward in the Committee on Budgets on behalf of our group.
We have not resubmitted this amendment, but the Green Party parliamentary group has resubmitted the motion again, supported by 40 signatures from Green parliamentarians.
We will abstain from this application.

However, having fundamentally stated that we, as a parliamentary group, will not be submitting any new amendment proposals, we will abstain.

I would, however, like to state explicitly that we support this point, the financial transaction tax, and hope that our colleagues on the other side of the House will support us in the votes in the coming days.
I believe it is important that we do not use national tax systems to counteract the internal market.
And this is particularly important in the context of cross-border services. Equal treatment is required here.
We now have a negative example in Hungary, where retroactive price caps were introduced as a crisis taxation measure.
That is unacceptable, particularly the financial, insurance, and commercial sectors, but also energy, which is heavily affected here.
I hope that this will not also be employed in the field of healthcare services in the future.
I would also like to ask President Orbán to review these arrangements, as they fundamentally contravene the concept of the internal market.
It is important that the EU addresses the problems of migration and asylum law.
The Commission has submitted corresponding proposals.
Currently, there is still no precise analysis of the implementation of existing legal regulations.
Likewise, there are scarcely any well-developed calculations and analyses concerning the new proposals.
I must state that the EPP unequivocally affirms the right to asylum and the right to protection for those in need of protection.
However, the consideration of reality unfortunately also leads us to the problem that the right of asylum is being claimed for entirely different reasons or even deliberately abused.
The right to asylum and subsidiary protection is not an instrument for the general immigration of the 27 member states.
We must also ensure that organized human traffickers do not get the opportunity, through our asylum law, to profit to the tune of billions from the fate of people.
Asylum procedures must be conducted in a qualified and thorough manner.
Persecuted individuals must have the guarantee of finding protection within the EU.
Therefore, the Commission intends to include corresponding obligations in the new drafts.
I find many of these points to be correct, such as interpreter services, appropriate medical care, and consideration of particular protection needs.
However, I also want to mention points that I consider problematic.
The authorities in Member States have far too few opportunities to prevent abuse.
The possibility of conducting expedited proceedings and border procedures should not be unduly restricted.

When an applicant seriously violates their obligation to cooperate, there are few options for sanctions. Quite the opposite. If they abscond illegally, the member state should no longer be able to conclude the proceedings negatively for them. If they reappear, they should be provided with a broader range of procedural options.
Even in cases of obvious lack of merit, an expedited procedure should be possible following the second successive application.
This signifies substantial cost increases.
Also, free legal advice in the form of a lawyer entails a significant increase in costs for the states, according to the current wording of the Commission’s draft.
I simply ask the Commission to reconsider the consequences of its proposals for practical reality, the financial implications, and the problems for the administration of the Member States.
We aim for a high standard, but it must also be feasible and, above all, should not place particularly burdened member states before entirely impossible tasks.
Mr. President, thank you very much for allowing me to briefly take the floor again.
I have a significant request of you, Commissioner Fühle.
I want to begin by stating that false assumptions lead to inaccurate cost estimates.
We are currently not seeing decreasing figures in the asylum seeker area, but rather a significantly increasing number.
That relates to visa facilitations, for example, with Serbia and Macedonia.
We are currently witnessing a massive increase in the abuse of asylum law in an attempt to enter a country of the European Union.

When one proceeds from false assumptions, namely that rejecting the initial proceedings in a higher-level reform would thereby save costs in subsequent instances, one automatically assumes that, so to speak, all Member States have a deficient initial proceeding.
That is not the case.
When one increases standards overall, it consequently implies that cost increases will result.
An increase in quality standards for everyone, as well as the complication of procedures, I am happy to discuss, but in practical reality, it leads to higher costs.
Therefore, I earnestly request once again to truly take the concerns of the states seriously, as the practical reports from the states are partly available and will also be provided.
Thank you, Mr. President. Dear colleagues, this report certifies that the Commission has pursued a successful competition policy.
However, it must not be forgotten that unregulated competition can also contribute to rising unemployment and a widening gap between the rich and the poor.
Unfettered competition still ranks higher within the European Union than the social needs of its people.
The credo of free markets cannot disguise the fact that they not only repeatedly fail but are also incapable of establishing social justice permanently.
Some procedures regarding distortion of competition and price fixing simply do not resolve this problem.
A fair and, at the same time, social internal market functions only with strong and equitable regulation.
More is urgently needed for that.
It is, for example, not acceptable to perpetually subject public utility services to private sector competition.
The report formulates recommendations for the Commission’s future competition policy.
Much stronger consumer protection, the exemption of public utility services from competition rules, and the control of cartels—all of this is urgently needed.
Furthermore, a contractual clause for secured social progress would be necessary, one that stands at least on an equal footing with the competition rules in Europe.
Ladies and gentlemen, it is a truly significant hour that we are commemorating, for the first time, the Holocaust of Roma and Sinti here in the European Parliament.
And let me begin with the farewell letter that a 14-year-old boy, Robert Reinhardt, wrote in 1943 before his deportation from a German children's home to Auschwitz.
He wrote that I had found my parents again.
We are being transported to the concentration camp.
I have steeled myself inwardly to the point that I can endure death.
I thank you once again for all you have done for me.
Greetings to all, farewell in heaven.
Yours, Robert.

Ladies and gentlemen, this boy did not return, like 500,000 other Roma and Sinti. And although Roma and Sinti, together with Jews, were among the first victims of industrialized mass murder, the full truth about it remains unspoken today, 66 years later.
And also the complicity of the mainstream society is often obscured.
We need the whole truth about this chapter of history.
The Holocaust against Roma and Sinti must be prosecuted as a crime against humanity and acknowledged, so that this history does not repeat itself.
We must passionately combat the prejudices against these people.
We must put an end to racist hostility and acts of violence, such as those that occurred in Hungary last year, and do so with civic courage.
Freedom and equality and solidarity are not a privilege of individuals, but the right of all, because human and civil rights are indivisible. Thank you.
Yes, most esteemed ladies and gentlemen, colleagues, from my perspective, it is now about truly realizing the possibilities of the law within the
to maximize the potential of robust financial supervision in Europe. And we have doubts as to whether institutions are truly maximizing these possibilities.
We see deficiencies in the procedure. As Parliament, we have not received the candidate list in advance to date, but only the finalized result.
It would be straightforward to send it to the Executive Directors now.

We have a clear deficit in gender equality regarding the filling of positions, and we have doubts, due to certain occurrences in the process, whether the member states are truly appointing individuals in the European interest to this institution.
and to legitimize the further points in our letter, a fundamental question needs to be raised.
But beyond that, it naturally concerns the suitability of the individual persons. And in that case, each person must be assessed individually and according to their competencies.
There, we see two major problems.

We have experienced in hearings that one of the candidates questioned whether it was a European institution, instead speaking of a network of supervisory authorities and, even upon request, was not willing to correct this.
When asked whether they are prepared to make all lobbying contacts with the financial industry transparent, we did not receive any clear statements.
We have sent a letter to all three candidates, and for us, the outcome of the vote depends on whether we receive clear and comprehensive answers to it.
Thank you, Mr. President. Mr. President, as the Social Democratic parliamentary group, we too wish to submit a motion.
However, I would like to recommend to my colleague Mauro and to this assembly that we formulate it somewhat more precisely.
We are dealing with a rather substantial influx.

And Italy, like every other country in the Mediterranean, is certainly overwhelmed by the prospect of managing the current problem alone. And certainly, Italy will not be the only country confronted with this mass influx of refugees.
We can assume that Malta, Greece, and Spain, too, will be confronted with this problem in the foreseeable future.

Therefore, we would request that the title of the statement be formulated very precisely, namely a statement by the Commission regarding immediate measures by the European Union to support Italy and other EU countries affected in managing the influx of refugees.
Madam President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, I expressly welcome the outcome of the conciliation procedure.

The implementation of the regulation will achieve the goal that, firstly, in the sector of coach transport, a high level of protection, comparable to that of other modes of transport, is established for all passengers, including those with limited mobility.

Firstly, to achieve benefits for citizens, secondly, to ensure a high general level of consumer protection, and thirdly, to take account of the fact that the sector is largely characterized by small and medium-sized enterprises.

Consequently, the extreme subsidies that would have rendered bus services virtually impossible due to excessive support are off the table, as are subsidies under which the majority of Member States would have fallen entirely outside the scope of the Regulation.
Public transport services that benefit the public at large must also offer a high quality of service to people with disabilities and those with limited mobility.
You should be entitled to assistance. In the interest of social integration, this should be free of charge.

Thank you, Madam Chair. I would like to congratulate everyone, particularly my colleague Mr. Kanzian, for his efforts in the difficult and protracted elaboration of a compromise in this challenging dossier.
There were successes, which have already been enumerated, but there were also disappointments, such as the scope and other subtleties, which have already been outlined.
With this compromise for bus transport, we have covered passenger rights for all modes of transportation.
The next necessary step is to create a common, coherent, and efficient framework for all passenger rights.
Fair and clearly defined rights are of particular importance for the credibility of the EU among European citizens.
To maintain credibility, therefore, the coherence of rights for the various modes of transport must be strictly respected.
There is no other way for the rights of airplane passengers. Fundamentally different criteria apply than, for example, for train passengers.

Therefore, it is particularly important when developing a framework program not to adhere to the lowest and weakest standards, but to ensure that we do not lose sight of ambitious goals in the interests of the citizens.

Madam President, esteemed Mr. President, dear colleagues, we are indeed in a major economic crisis—that is something we have been discussing for months, and that is true. However, we typically speak in headlines and then proceed to make decisions here as if nothing had happened.
I believe it is due to the fact that we in parliament, too, do not behave concretely or honestly enough, but rather it is such a policy of headlines that occurs.
What, in reality, does one actually do to foster growth and stability?
Do we ourselves also contribute to handling finances more properly and wisely?
Have we truly undertaken a critical examination of whether we are making the right expenditures, or does not each of us, every day, simply have a new idea about where more money can be spent?

If we do not have the strength to concentrate financial resources on future projects—that is, disagreement, debate, and decision—then there is no point in talking about innovation and research but not providing the means to support them.
is relatively dishonest.
And if we want to stimulate the economy, then we must also pursue policies that stimulate it, and not spend from morning till night pondering how to disrupt industry or the economy.
We cheerfully continue to pass resolutions, demanding new resolutions even today, which disrupt economic developments.
Does anyone truly believe that the question of binding energy-efficient settlements, to name just one example, contributes to economic progress?
Do you genuinely believe that our decisions, which you frequently made in relation to energy, have harmed the economy?
Or have we disturbed them?
And I would like us to be a bit more honest about this and then also make a few fewer decisions, but perhaps make the decisions that truly move things forward.
That is more laborious, more arduous, and will also mean disagreements, but that is the point of democracy.
Yes, thank you. Colleagues, the demand for a financial transaction tax is not new. For several years, opponents of globalization have been calling for such a tax.
Yet, just five years ago, few would have believed that they could be implemented in the foreseeable future.
But this week, it is on the agenda in the European Parliament alongside a carbon tax and Eurobonds, and I think that is a good thing.
I can only welcome and support the financial instruments proposed by Anni Podimata in her report, and I believe we will also vote accordingly.
They are urgently needed instruments.
The consolidation of public budgets has thus far focused solely on reducing expenditures.
The reduction of public expenditure primarily affects employees, pensioners, and the poor – that is, those who depend on the welfare state.
The revenue side of public administration has hitherto been completely overlooked.
It is the second adjustment knob one can turn to consolidate public budgets.
Above all, however, those primarily responsible for the public debt crisis and the reduction of public debt can also be appropriately involved on the revenue side.
To consolidate public budgets, an increase in tax revenue is simply indispensable.

In fact, the high level of public debt is primarily a consequence of the nationalization of private debts, namely the assumption of private banks’ liabilities and the financing of the subsequent financial crisis by the public sector.
The responsibility for the debt crisis, therefore, does not rest solely with the states.
It is therefore not only logical, but also politically necessary, to call the financial sector to account.
The financial transaction tax would finally involve this sector, now recognized as a primary contributor to public debt, in the reduction of that debt.
This constitutes an important political signal emanating from this report, should it be adopted as presented.
But we also consider Eurobonds to be a sensible and therefore necessary instrument.
They contribute more to debt reduction than all sanctions or well-intentioned advice.

The complaints of some surplus countries that their interest burdens will increase as a result of Eurobonds are, however, unacceptable, since these surplus countries simultaneously also profit from their exports to the deficit countries.
That can then be criticized as a transfer union.
However, whoever desires a social Europe, whoever wants the EU to remain united in the future, must, in principle, at least agree to a transfer union.
Finally, I would like to address the Commission and express my hope that it will now present the proposals for a financial transaction tax, which have been requested for over a year. Thank you.
Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen, the rescue shields should protect EU member states from insolvency.
However, they are burdening people with brutal austerity programs and leaving the perpetrators unscathed. Furthermore, the Commission is now also intervening in national wage policies.

This position is entirely unacceptable. Wage policy is not the responsibility of the EU. This policy of the Commission stands in blatant contradiction to the idea of this European Union.
The European Union has never been a project for downward wage competition and social dumping.
there one reads of wage rigidity, which is to be reduced.
to discuss, wages should reflect market conditions.

I want to state clearly: this Parliament is required to ensure the preservation of autonomous collective bargaining policy, to protect social dialogue, and to prevent further dismantling of social security.
We need measures against counterproductive austerity policies and punitive actions. Thank you.
Mr. Barroso, you are a clever man, but you have not answered my question.

Because, in my view, that is a real danger.
Mrs. Gabriele Zimmer has the floor. I would actually like to ask the two representatives from the Council and the Commission why they believe they need to address this topic with prepared statements.
I believe it helps no one if it is not explicitly stated that, in preparation for the Istanbul Conference, the member states of the European Union and the European Union itself...
must finally fully meet their commitments for development aid and that it cannot in any way be tolerated that Member States increasingly evade this obligation.

And then to talk about hoping that LDCs become more shock-resistant—I’m starting to find that cynical.
I urge you to address the problems specifically and clearly, and to assume concrete commitments in order to actually assist the LDC.
In the context of the internal market, public procurement law, the awarding of public contracts, is a crucial component.

Mr. Barnier, if you say that you also want to promote social integration in this context, then I must ask you, I have heard little about the protection of social rights, I have heard little about the protection of collective bargaining agreements.
That belongs to the fundamental rules which you, as you say, do not wish to question yourself.

If one wishes to protect fundamental rules, it will be necessary in the future, when awarding public contracts, to ensure that elementary social standards are protected, that collective bargaining agreements are not undermined, and that wage dumping is prevented.
This is part of a modernized public procurement law.
And I expressly state that social basic rights must no longer be subordinated to economic freedoms and free competition.
Either we want a social Europe, or we want a permanent conflict with those people who are turning away from this Europe in which they do not see their vital interests safeguarded. Thank you.
Dear Madam President, Dear Commissioner Krus, radio frequencies are a precious and limited resource that must be managed with care, foresight, and consideration of societal aspects as a whole.
Therefore, the Radio Spectrum Policy Program holds particular significance.
Radio frequencies must be utilized efficiently, taking into account economic, social, and cultural aspects.
To achieve this, technical capabilities must be utilized to their fullest extent across all bandwidth areas to generate maximum efficiency.

The basis of radio frequency policy must be the telecommunications package adopted last year. For it is here that it was stipulated that radio frequency management for the EU and its member states must equally satisfy cultural, social, and economic interests.
This must be considered particularly when harmonizing frequency usage within the EU.
In this context, I would like to point out that the implementation of the digital dividend I has proceeded at a markedly varied pace in the member states.
A further opening of the ORF band, particularly below 800 MHz, should therefore only be considered after taking into account the experiences gained in clearing this band.
Many technical and financial questions have not yet been definitively resolved.

The issue of interference and the question of cost compensation for cultural institutions and local authorities during technical upgrades, for example in the area of radio microphones, has not yet been satisfactorily resolved.
When allocating frequency bands, the diverse interests must be responsibly balanced against one another.

Widespread provision of mobile broadband networks, on the one hand, is a fundamental requirement in the interest of European citizens. Simultaneously, however, continued development in the areas of public and private broadcasting must also be considered as an important instrument for information and cultural diversity.
We must set the course correctly for technical development, Europe’s positioning in the field of digital information technology, and cultural diversity.
Mr. President, dear Mr. Rehn, I would first like to say that, as you have described, the situation has worsened.

When will the Commission present it?

What are you doing to make it go faster?

We still have absolutely rising interest burdens macroeconomically for these countries.
We are experiencing increasing capital exports and capital flight in some of these countries.

and we have rising resource and food prices, at least if one disregards recent fluctuations.
