Mr. President, esteemed colleagues, and dear guests, Europe’s cultural diversity is a valuable asset that must be preserved and further developed in the future.
To make this possible, we must confront the challenges of the digital age not only in the information and knowledge society, but above all in the cultural and creative sector.
Cultural diversity is not only an ideal value, but it also represents a significant economic factor.
Approximately five million people are employed in the cultural sector within the EU.
This corresponds to approximately 2.5% of total employment.
The cultural sector is a growth sector, developing faster than many areas of the wider economy.

The development of information and communication technologies is driven just as much by the content offered by the cultural sector as the nature and quality of that content have been changed and advanced by technology.
Therefore, we need to establish framework conditions for the culture and creative industries that will enable them to develop sustainably in light of the challenges of the digital age.
We require a modern, accessible, and legally secure system in which everyone can develop equally.
The cultural and creative industries are a driving force for Europe.
Therefore, we must also focus on this area within the realm of vocational and academic education.
We must impart cultural and creative competencies to young people and also within the offerings of lifelong learning.
However, we must also better strengthen the entrepreneurial skills of cultural creators. And not only entrepreneurial competencies, but also a good media literacy in the field of new technologies.
We need frameworks that enable cultural practitioners to secure their livelihoods.

And for this reason, we will need to engage intensively with the questions of copyright, social security, and intellectual property, but also with the issue of open access to information and content, in order to facilitate the advancement

to ensure the future of the creative and cultural industries in a digital environment and to preserve Europe’s cultural diversity and cultural heritage as an essential characteristic of the European Union.
Mr. President, dear colleague Kellam, esteemed colleagues from the Baltic states, dear colleagues, today we commemorate, in particular, the expulsions and mass deportations from the Baltic states.
These expulsions belong to the darkest events in European history.
Indeed, the past century was called, not least and not unjustly, a century of expulsions.
And we all bow our heads today in respect for the victims of these inhumane acts.
In this connection, we demand a comprehensive investigation of Soviet history and, in particular, the atrocities of Stalinism.

And today's Russia should not interpret this as a political attack, but rather as support for the examination of its own history, which, like the history of other European countries, is characterized by both bright and dark aspects.
But just as we think of the victims from the Baltic countries, we think of the Armenians who were expelled from Turkey at the beginning of the last century.
We reflect upon the so-called population exchange between Turkey and Greece.
The deportations in Europe reached a particular peak in the mid-century through the Nazi regime and through the communist regime of the Soviet Union.
Expulsions following the Second World War also left deep wounds, as did the expulsions during the Yugoslav Wars.
However, we must also not forget that many colonial regimes were characterized by displacement.
We must demand a serious engagement with the various forms of displacement and the specious justifications thereof.
And that includes clarifying guilt and punishing the guilty, to the extent that is still possible, as is now the case with Mladic, for example.
But the decisive answer is European unity, particularly through and with the independent Baltic states, and a clear commitment to continuing the still-incomplete European integration process.
This historical task is what we owe not only to ourselves but, especially, to the victims of the numerous expulsions in Europe.
Many female politicians from across Europe, from East and West, have worked on it.
Let us consider, for example, the Tanzig Declaration, signed by the Polish President Wozniowski and the German Federal President Rauch.
And because we want to learn from the past, we must be vigilant, even towards initial signs of displacement, as in the case of the Roma.

We must reject all such statements, for example, the assertion that Arabic migrants should be returned in boats across the Mediterranean. And we must stand firm against those who wish to dismantle the achievements of a Europe without borders and return to a narrow-minded nationalism.
Let us bow in reverence before all victims of displacement and deportation, but let us unanimously commit to the continuation of European unification, as the only true guarantee against a
Politics that brought so much misfortune to the people of Europe, but also beyond. Never to forget, never again were demands that arose immediately after the Second World War.
They have lost none of their validity. You are best protected in a united Europe. Thank you.

Thank you, Madam President, Commissioner, my esteemed ladies and gentlemen, dear colleagues. I had the opportunity, as an observer of the Parliament, to witness the referendum on the independence of South Sudan. And I was impressed by the great desire of South Sudanese citizens to determine the future of their country themselves.
And I also observed the widespread expectation among the people, who viewed their country’s independence as liberation from slavery.

Thousands, perhaps tens of thousands, of so-called Internally Displaced Persons, driven by decades of conflict in the south to refugee camps in the north, embarked on the journey to their former homeland in South Sudan.

And of course, the people of South Sudan, alongside the country’s independence, above all desire to live in peace and to embark on a path toward a happier future, after all the decades of armed conflicts in which millions of South Sudanese had to lose their lives.
On July 9th, the new state of South Sudan is now slated to officially become independent and expand the family of nations in our world.
The starting conditions are exceedingly unfavorable. And much has already been said about that here.
70% of the people live as normalizing livestock breeders; 80% are illiterate. The conflict surrounding Abiyé is escalating into a military conflict.
There were already dead and wounded there.
As if that were not enough, rivalries between tribes and armed groups in South Sudan are also escalating, and observers estimate that over 1000 people have already lost their lives since January.
The wounded and the violated are scarcely counted.
Sudan already belonged to the category of failed states.
There is a risk that the state of South Sudan is already beginning to resemble a failed state.
I am firmly convinced that there is a significant obligation of Europe towards this region.
in light of the colonial past of those countries. Together with the UN and the African Union, a common European foreign policy is required here and can prove itself here as well.
It is not only about money, but also about supporting the delicate, emerging civil society.

And we must negotiate rigorously with those who hold the fate of the country in their hands, namely, the tribal leaders, the commanders of the military groups, so that they do not betray the hopes of their people within the country. Thank you very much.

Thank you, Madam President, Mr Commissioner, colleagues. I am very grateful to my colleague Bartolozzi for having initiated this request, making Mongolia the subject of a debate in the European Parliament.
While the formerly Soviet states of Central Asia are now treated in Parliament from various perspectives, Mongolia and its situation found only scant resonance here.
Quite wrongly, it was Mongolia that, as a state of the former communist bloc, quite early utilized its independence and embarked on a path toward the democratization of its society.

As early as 1992, Mongolia adopted a democratic constitution, and several elections have since taken place, which, according to observers, proceeded overall democratically and correctly—a development that is far from a given in states of this region.

The Mongolian government has been attempting to combat corruption through legislation for several years and issued a moratorium on the death penalty in 2010, a feat that even some large democratic states have yet to achieve.
Nevertheless, the three million inhabitants of this geographically large country, dominated by extreme climatic conditions, are suffering from the consequences of an ongoing transformation process.
Thus, a predominantly nomadic rural population is pressing into the few cities that are not prepared infrastructurally for this influx.
The country’s natural resources are not being extracted in an environmentally sound manner.
Energy problems are complicating civilian and economic life.
Squeezed between the large neighbors Russia and China, Mongolia is threatened with becoming even more dependent on these states than before.

The efforts and the successes of Mongolia – and here I see the glass half full, not half empty – should be recognized, as they are exemplary for this region and demonstrate what is possible despite a difficult past.

And Mongolia should continue to receive our support, not only within the framework of aid programs, but also by ensuring that the European Union is directly present in the Mongolian capital with its own representation.

Representation as a sign that the fate of Mongolia and Europeans is not a matter of indifference, and that European interests will no longer be pursued from the representation in Peking. One sentence, please.

Thank you, Madam President. Dear Commissioner, esteemed colleagues. After nearly three years of intensive work, after far more than 3,000 amendments, after countless conversations and discussions,

Following the most difficult technical negotiations and political trilogue sessions, it is now up for a vote. The political package – a major compromise between the European Parliament and the Council – concerning the future labeling of foodstuffs.
This regulation aims to provide consumers with more and better information about food products, enabling them to make informed purchasing decisions.
But that is not all. The European food industry is also to benefit.
Legal certainty, deregulation, and improved legislation are the objectives.
This is particularly important for small and medium-sized enterprises. And it is essential to know that the food sector in the European Union consists of SMEs to over 80 percent.
Simultaneously, this labeling must be appropriate for every food and every non-alcoholic beverage. From staple foods to highly processed ready meals.
Therefore, a mandatory labelling system using traffic light colours is also not possible, because this labelling simply does not suit basic foodstuffs.

Despite all the difficulties, despite all the political and ideological differences within Parliament, despite all the national egoisms of the member states, the compromise now achieved is nonetheless impressive.
Allergens will be clearly identifiable at first glance.
The plant origin of vegetable oils is indicated.
There is an origin indication for pork, poultry, lamb, and goat meat.

For further products, a consequence assessment will demonstrate whether and how the origin can be indicated, for example, for milk and dairy products, single ingredients—that is, products consisting of a primary ingredient—and meat in processed
Imitations, etc., must be clearly marked on the front and the same applies to form meats and form fish composed of, or assembled from, small pieces.
Furthermore, packaging must not create the impression that something is included that is, in fact, not present.
If a product depicts fruit on its packaging, it must also contain fruit and not merely colorants and flavorings.
In addition, the mandatory declaration of the most important nutrients, always per 100 grams or 100 milliliters, is required for the sake of comparability.
Added water in meat must be indicated, the date of the first deep freezing for meat and fish, and many other details.
Above all, however, all entries must be legible.

We have defined readability, we have established a minimum font size, and the commission has been tasked with defining binding rules for further factors, such as the contrast between the text and the background.
At the same time, we are protecting crafts from excessively high costs and bureaucracy.
Non-prepackaged fresh products must provide allergen information, but not the complete nutritional information, which requires costly analyses to determine.

The Commission did originally want this, but that would have destroyed our national and regional peculiarities and specialties. It would have led to a European homogenized mass, and that is why we prevented it.
But now we have all agreed, and the reputable consumer advocates are quite satisfied with what has been achieved.

Madam President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, in light of the currently exceptional situation resulting from the financial, economic, and budgetary crisis, decisions at the European level should focus on urgent and essential matters.
Only in this way can we restore trust among our citizens in the seriousness of our actions.
My report concerns the strategy for avoiding endless human suffering, resulting from approximately 35,000 deaths and incapacitations annually.
4.5 million instances of severe injuries as a result of traffic accidents, as well as to avoid the associated economic damage of 130 billion euros annually.
The number of fatalities alone is equivalent to that which would be mourned in the crash of 250 fully occupied medium-sized commercial aircraft.
What wouldn’t we do to prevent that?
The costs resulting from accidents considerably exceed the annual total budget of the European Union.
Therefore, I am certain that it would serve us well to become sustainably active in this area.

Thanks to the constructive collaboration of all shadow rapporteurs as well as many colleagues, for the first time with this report we have succeeded in developing a unified, holistic, and coherent approach to improving road safety.

He takes into account the content of the UN Decade of Action for Road Safety 2010–2020, as well as the content and objectives of road safety efforts undertaken by EU member states and broader segments of civil society.
It first includes ambitious, yet realistic goals for the period until 2020 and with Sirum’s vision for the time thereafter.

Therefore, the aim is to reduce the number of fatalities in accidents by 50 percent, the number of child fatalities even by 60 percent, and the number of severely injured individuals by 40 percent by 2020.
That lies in the most fundamental interest of each and every one of our people, but also in our national economy.
We recommend that the Member States break down targets and methods to their territory and expect them to develop their own road safety action programmes.
Secondly, it specifies who is responsible for the individual activities and measures.
This is far from being solely the European Union.

In the spirit of subsidiarity, the holistic approach means that Member States, regionally or locally responsible companies, and even each individual road user, in the interest of their duty of cooperation, must assume responsibility.
And thirdly, it includes how – that is, with which instruments, activities, and measures – the objectives are to be achieved.
Legislative proposals at the European level are only one strategy.
We cannot and do not want to forgo guidelines, recommendations, or assignments.
Particular attention has been paid to subsidiarity. This means that responsibilities and accountabilities have been clearly defined, even where they are shared.
We appreciate the commission's diverse activities.

However, as they originate from the most diverse directorates-general, such as Transport, Economy, Consumer Protection, Environment, Communications, Research and Development, Internal Market, and others, they are not always coherent, often uncoordinated, and sometimes contradict one another.
Therefore, we propose the establishment of a road safety coordinator within the European Commission.
This permanently avoids the establishment of an agency for road safety, but considerably increases the efficiency of the European Commission.
Both the selection of measures and their evaluation require a scientifically grounded approach based on comparable, high-quality data, definitions, and statistics.
Therefore, we are calling for, among other things, a harmonized analysis of injury and accident causes as well as EU-wide data exchange while maintaining a high level of personal data protection.
Six key areas of action were identified.
They concern the individual as a road user, traffic regulations, vehicles, infrastructure, their intelligent networking, and the particular consideration of vulnerable road users.
I request your approval tomorrow.

yet what does the council do in this situation?

If, in the current political climate, a reasonable budget increase cannot be achieved, then Parliament and the Commission should nevertheless do everything possible to ward off the cuts proposed by the Council. Thank you.

until it makes things more difficult. Mrs. Zimmer, you have the laptop, please. Yes, thank you very much, Mrs. Zimmer. Ladies and gentlemen, it is precisely in this crisis that we see what kind of European Union we actually want.
Do we want a union in which the binding element truly consists of the mortar that says we don’t care whether people have to live in poverty in any country within a member state of the European Union?
we see ourselves as jointly responsible for combating poverty and social exclusion.
Or do we opt for a union as it has just been sketched out by colleagues from the far-right factions of this Parliament as well?

Sometimes I believe that we, with the attitude of the member states and, in particular, some governments of these member states, are dangerously close to that vision of a European Union as formulated by the far right.
Do nothing shared, establish no shared instruments, set no shared indicators, use vague formulations wherever possible.
The interim report makes this very, very clear in many respects, and I believe we need to become significantly stronger here.
What we need is an immediate halt to the sell-off of public goods, the sell-off of social security systems.
We need social and ecological minimum standards.
Given the impending winter, it must not happen again that people end up on the street, are evicted, and ultimately freeze to death due to rising energy prices.
Here, we bear a shared responsibility, the responsibility as the European Union.
For that, we must stand up, not for this nationalist bluster, which we have heard from the right wing.

What advice would we have given our colleagues in 1931 or 1938, when we were in the Depression, when the financial markets had already undermined the democracies, and when we were heading towards wars?
I believe two things would be necessary. Two emergency measures. We need something like a transitional government.
Do what you must do, swiftly. Do not let yourself be slowed down. Regulate every product, every institute, and every player as Frau Möller does.
Merkel has said. But a transitional government alone, which implements the austerity program, cannot have a future if there is no emergency program for democratic policy.

That is to say, in this case, we naturally need a European Community, we naturally need other treaties, we naturally need a system that functions, but one that only gains legitimacy and is considered legitimate if there are referendums.

And we must already advocate for the fact that the situation has become so dramatic that a fundamental shift in thinking is necessary, before the right-wing extremists, before those who promote national divisions, regain control over something that was actually already being built.
Thank you, Madam Chair. There is no doubt that this esteemed assembly is committed to transparency and openness toward the citizenry.
My EPP Group does so as well, of course.
But the present report goes far beyond the original objective.
Existing legislation and interinstitutional agreements are disregarded. The protection of competitive procedures, sensitive, and personal data is neglected.
That, among other things, severely violates data protection, for which we advocate so strongly elsewhere.
Should we now sacrifice the privacy of the global public?
Precisely this danger exists with the present report, because administrative procedures and decisions – which, for example, also include personnel matters – are to be published.
The same applies to the protection of trade secrets and sensitive information within the context of approval procedures, court proceedings, and competition proceedings.

With its vague, imprecise, and overly broad definitions, the report permits public access even to such documents. This is because a document is defined as all data and content standing in any connection with the policies, measures, and decisions of all bodies and institutions of the EU.
This includes preparatory, confidential, and secret documents, as well as all associated information.
And thus, this definition encompasses not only documents, but also information.
Also, information from ongoing interinstitutional proceedings, such as from informal trilogue negotiations, should be published.
Do you know, Mr. Rapporteur, because truly, what does that mean?

It means public access to the process. It means public influence on the decision-making process. Then we might as well seat the lobbyists at the table and let them negotiate. Is that what the citizens want?
I cannot imagine it.
In addition, documents related to non-legislative procedures, measures of internal administrative organization, etc., should also be published. Where is the public interest in that?
Or would it not rather impede our work?
I believe this report was not created in the spirit of our citizens.
He would unleash a flood of useless information.
He would render our work impossible and, above all, you have heard it from the commissioner, he is unacceptable to the other institutions because he violates existing rules and laws.
You know that, Mr. Rapporteur, and fundamentally you are working against further transparency and against the citizen. Thank you.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, esteemed colleagues, when dealing with a topic as important and comprehensive as the White Paper on the Future of Transport, there is always a risk of ending up with a Christmas tree, where everyone tries to incorporate their two or three pet themes.
When one examines the result that will be put to a vote tomorrow, then one can without a doubt congratulate our rapporteur, Mathieu Grosch.

He managed to develop a good, coherent, and manageable result from several hundred proposals, which prioritizes safety, environmental protection, energy, and technology as the main focuses for the future of transport.
I explicitly welcome the fact that important issues such as the social, health, and labor law conditions of employees are also appropriately mentioned here.

This is particularly important in light of the looming skills shortage in the transport sector, which requires active intervention if future bottlenecks in well-trained specialists are to be prevented.
Further liberalization of cabotage in road transport only on the condition that social dumping and unfair conditions are prevented.
I also welcome the fact that the aspect of improving road safety is given a significant place here.
The safety on our roads is a matter that will continue to concern us in the future.
I view other points with greater criticality.
I would have preferred a statement regarding the model ship, where more emphasis would be placed on shifting traffic from the road to the rail and waterways.
And I also find this argument to be not the best solution for greater sustainability regarding the discussion of Giga-liners.
Equally critical, one should await and reconsider the further liberalization of the railway sector and the opening up of national passenger transport.
There remain technical harmonization and fair competitive conditions to resolve.

But as I said, in this report, I hope that the expectations of Parliament expressed here do not remain a pious wish list, but that a goal is achieved by 2020 and our proposals have become reality. Thank you.
It has been only 20 years since the Central Asian states gained their statehood as a result of the dissolution of the Soviet Union.
Emerging from a dictatorship, the establishment of democratic and rule-of-law structures in these states remains a persistent challenge.
Nevertheless, these states are important trading partners of the EU and its member states due to their wealth of mineral resources and raw materials.
It is therefore only logical to regulate the EU's relations with these states within the framework of partnership and cooperation agreements.
Partnership and cooperation agreements are intended to facilitate collaboration and foster a spirit of partnership, but not to lead to one-sided stigmatization.
Child labor, and particularly forced child labor, remains an unfortunately widespread scourge in many countries of the world, and must be combatted.

I do, however, point out that it was customary in many European regions shaped by agriculture to extend children's school holidays during harvest time and to allow children from farming families the opportunity to assist with the harvest, which would not be considered forced labor today.
However, should there be indications of child labor in Uzbekistan during the cotton harvest, consequences must be drawn.

The same consequence, however, must apply to all other states where child labor still exists, including those states where we pursue economic interests of a vastly different magnitude, such as in India or China.
We should not apply double standards here.
Mr. President of the Council, Mr. President of the Commission, esteemed colleagues, I wholeheartedly join the ranks that have already offered their congratulations to the Council Presidency.
You were not only an honest broker in difficult times, but you were also a European broker.

I believe that was very pleasant to feel during these difficult times, when we have political currents in a variety of member states suggesting to people that one can achieve more alone than together.
and you have highlighted the commonalities.
And it was also very refreshing to witness that you have found approval among the people in Poland, even in the domestic political discourse, with this clear European agenda.
It wasn’t entirely straightforward in this context.
and also the highest respect for what you have achieved.
We have been able to initiate quite a few things over the past six months, particularly in the area of financial market regulation.

If I may single out just one area where I personally had the opportunity to negotiate, namely the question of regulation concerning short sales and uncovered credit default swaps on government bonds, where the Commission hesitated to propose a stringent regulation, where we were met by all

Member states were told, you will not prevail, and where, thanks to the Polish Council Presidency, it has been possible to sanction such a highly speculative instrument and where it is necessary to also prohibit it, so that we can contribute to greater stability in the financial markets.
I would like to express my sincere thanks to your Minister of Finance and the State Secretary, who initiated this through a laborious discussion process between Parliament and the Council.
This is an example of what can be achieved together in the interest of security and stability in Europe.
Mr. Steers, thank you kindly for that.
Since yesterday, colleagues, the new surveillance mechanism for economic imbalances is in effect.
Meanwhile, the concrete substantive regulations are also in place.
Which developments does the Commission now consider dangerous? Which economic problems does it wish to have corrected?
The Commission considers a growth of hourly labor costs in Eurozone countries exceeding 3% per year to be a problem.
A limit for decreasing wages, however, is not planned.
Dear Commissioner, inexpensive does not necessarily mean good.
It is not enough to trim the member states to achieve prosperity at the expense of trading partners.
Without investments in education, healthcare, and energy efficiency, we may exploit our workers to the bone, but we will not write economic success stories.
Another example from the scoreboard. The loss of export market share is to be reviewed and sanctioned.
That is nonsense.
With increasing global trade, Europe’s statistical share inevitably declines at the
Consequently, the indicator penalizes countries already integrated into global trade.
Therefore, we believe that the Commission should withdraw this basket and subject it to a complete overhaul. Thank you.

Madam President, Commissioner, esteemed colleagues, I would first like to join in thanking our rapporteur and all those who contributed to the report, because it is not a routine matter, even though we are addressing competition policy based on a Commission report for the 40th time.
I owe the Commissioner a great deal of thanks, as 2010 was the year in which you were for the first time fully responsible for competition policy, for that very comprehensive presentation.

However, I would still like to express the request, and you have just addressed this in your contribution, that we need to make some progress, particularly in the area of subsidies, of public subsidies in the banking sector.
should occur, as a new capitalization within the banking sector is once again being urged due to the new stress test of the European Banking Authority.
and I don't believe that this contributes to the stability of the banking system when, on the one hand, we still have a multitude of unresolved or outstanding legacy cases.
We are, in fact, already seeing new cases arise because corresponding pressure is being built to increase the equity ratio, particularly in the area of private banks.

Therefore, here my urgent request, Mr. Commissioner, to arrive at a swift resolution that also contributes to stabilizing the banking sector, enabling it to meet the challenges of the international environment.
The second major topic, merger control, will continue to occupy us significantly in the coming years.
Here, too, I can only urge the continuation of the previously clear and transparent path that the Commission has taken within the framework of merger control.

I believe that it is in the interest of all parties involved, particularly consumers, to ensure that competition remains possible in the area of merger control, even in larger or different structures—I don't want to judge those.
In that spirit, thank you to everyone who contributed here. And I hope, Mr. Commissioner, that we will soon arrive at a solution, particularly in the area of banking. Thank you.

Mr. Commissioner, I believe you have hit the nail on the head when we all collectively recognize that we are capable of initiating a third industrial revolution in Europe if we understand that we must perceive the sustainability opportunity as an industrial opportunity.
Then you also spoke of resources, and that reminds me of a thought I completely forgot today.
I have, in fact, forgotten the human resources in my office.
And Mrs. Philipp, allow me to say, you have worked like a horse. Successes wonderful, you were a very leading person in this matter.
And for that, I would like to express my sincere gratitude.
Thank you, Mr. President. Freedom of speech in parliament also requires a functioning microphone system.
The button for turning on the microphone has broken.
I would request that a technician restore the speak/communication freedom. Thank you.
Thank you, Madam President, Mr. Commissioner, esteemed colleagues. It surprises me that we repeatedly have to be reminded of what structural and cohesion policy actually entails.

Cohesion and structural policies represent one of the central policy areas of the European Union, and they are, by definition, intended to contribute to strengthening economic and social cohesion within the Community, with a particular focus on promoting growth and employment in underdeveloped regions.
The necessity and success of coalition and structural policy have been demonstrated, particularly during the years of crisis.
In many regions, the situation appears much more difficult. As far as economic development is concerned, these funds would not be available.
The implementation of the funding structure is achieved through operational programs, as has already been noted, which describe the funding strategy of the respective region.
The European Union, Member States, and regions collaborate here in a partnership, thereby creating genuine European added value.
The success of coalition and structural policy also relies on the reliability of the programs and the resources provided and available.

Therefore, I am very surprised when, repeatedly, from Member States and, as we now see, also from the Commission's side, attempts are made to treat the structural fund resources as a savings account for all sorts of current policy approaches.

This does not do justice to the sense and purpose of coalition politics and, furthermore, unsettles the actors in the regions who are already working towards achieving the goals based on long-term strategies and contracts.
Certainly, combating youth unemployment and advocating for economic growth are important objectives.

This will only be achieved, however, if the collaborative partnership between the regions, the Member States, and the Commission is maintained, and if the actors in the regions are involved and remain so.
Only you possess the knowledge of what needs to be done in your regions.
Cohesion and structural policy represent the unifying, collaborative, and solidarity-based bond of action between the various levels of policy within the European Union.
Within it, solidarity in Europe becomes tangible at the regional level, and it should not be lightly abandoned due to political expediency. Thank you very much.

Thank you, Mr. Chairman, Mr. Commissioner. I support the compromise found in Triod, which is intended to strengthen the negotiating power of dairy farmers vis-à-vis the processing industry, although I am aware that it does not solve all the problems currently faced by dairy farmers in some Member States.
Already, Commissioner Manzold had, 50 years ago within the framework of the GAP preferential measures for the establishment of producer organizations stipulated.
Even in my country, Luxembourg, dairy farming, due to the high proportion of grassland, is the main pillar of our agriculture.
Our farmers have long understood that the best solution is to join forces in a cooperative that handles the processing of milk itself.
Five member states voted against the compromise in the Council for precisely this reason, as it does not meet the requirements for it to function as a soft landing instrument.

The European Commission has the right of initiative with regard to legislative proposals, and therefore I would like to urge you to submit a legislative proposal to the Council and the European Parliament before the end of 2012, in order to remedy this obvious and costly error in the system.

A linear reduction of the supplementary levy until 2015, charged per kilogram of milk delivered, or the elimination of the fat correction could at least mitigate the negative effects of the expiring regulation, without harming member states not affected by it.
The present milk package is also intended as the final report of the High-Level Group, which aims to facilitate a soft landing for the abolition of milk quotas.
Remarkably, the report makes no mention whatsoever of milk quotas.
The young and ambitious farmers in Luxembourg and in four other member states, who are trying to prepare for the liberalization of the milk market and expand their production,
to remain competitive in the global market after 2015, they can only do so by purchasing additional quotas, even now, so shortly before the end of the milk quota system.
A massive additional and unnecessary capital expenditure, which disadvantages them compared to their counterparts in 22 member states. Thank you.
Here you are, the Blue Cut. Question: are you aware that we have community bonds already?
And that the resolution does not speak of Eurobonds in a blanket fashion, but rather of very different options,
and are you aware that not all of these options require a contract amendment?
I find it questionable that you have once again isolated generalities about Eurobonds here.
Precisely the level of nuance we have achieved here with Ms. Goulart’s excellent proposal is what we should not relinquish.
I would appreciate hearing a bit more differentiation in your statements and am eager to hear your thoughts on that.
I simply want to say, dear colleague Gulda, that this is not an evaluation I have undertaken here.
I merely want to point out that the last Italian government bond, before Italy entered the Euro, yielded 10%.
and there was no outcry in Italy, and no one said that other countries should take that over now.
It was, of course, standard practice to pay high interest rates.

and now suddenly, because we have had ten years of low interest rates and accumulated excessive debt, because money has become cheap, both for investments and for the public sector, then one wants to prolong this through Eurobonds.
This is a trap from which we cannot escape, and I stand by that.
Thank you very much, Inspector. Your reply has genuinely disappointed me somewhat.

You evidently want to retain the existing system, which necessitates complex negotiations per country and, in turn, restricts further access to literature, thus preventing the creation of more opportunities for blind and visually impaired individuals.
This is all the more regrettable for me, because the European Union is now blocking a step forward at WIPO, while all other or many other contracting parties would be prepared to move forward.
Here, a tremendous opportunity is being missed.

They are not fighting for extended rights for authors here, but rather against individuals to whom the Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities is intended to guarantee equal access to cultural goods, and who should also be able to participate comprehensively in these cultural goods.
I urge you, please dismantle barriers and agree to a binding treaty.

Dear colleagues, the discussion here within this institution demonstrates that we represent the entire spectrum of viewpoints. On one side, those who desire no restrictions whatsoever; on the other, those who equate every form of immigration with the threat of mass immigration.
These are the two extremes within this framework.
I believe that family reunification must be considered with great reason and expressed with rationality.
On the one hand, there are indeed problems in Member States where excessively restrictive measures are being taken.
For family reunification cannot be burdened with so many obstacles that, in the end, no one can be reunited at all.
On the other hand, it is entirely justified for member states to, for example, require language proficiency, to require integration, but also to require a willingness to integrate within a state.
Secondly, Member States naturally have the right, and we should not brush aside these problems, the problems that arise in family reunification, to articulate them.

If countries like Greece, or Malta, or indeed Romania or Italy are no longer permitted to articulate the problems they face, in part within this context, then I do not know whether we are democratic if we simply ignore problems.
I do not believe that we need a new guideline again just yet.
I believe we should carefully discuss the problems and then consider how we can eliminate them.
The constant re-issuance of guidelines does not lead to an improvement in the guidelines and their implementation.
We are currently experiencing partial implementation issues.

And I also fully understand the necessity of first addressing the fact that we mustn't create another new directive and add something to it before we have thoroughly discussed the problematic aspects of the existing directive in any way.
I am in favor of listening to the member states and simultaneously respecting the fundamental right to family reunification.
And if one does this with reason and understanding, then I also believe that we will arrive at a good path.
Mr. President, Pomyśl, Sanim, Pomyśl. Consider before you think, urges the Polish aphorist Stanislaw Wierzylec. And this recommendation would occasionally serve us well in this Parliament as well.
Few weeks after the resolution on the Central Asia strategy, adopted in this house, which assigned grades to the Central Asian states, attention is now turned to strike events in Janaozen.
in Kazakhstan, reflected without awaiting the results of ongoing investigations being conducted with international participation.

However deeply the deceased are to be mourned, and however the injured and those detained as a result of these events have a right to the processing of occurrences, the underlying reasons remain obscure.

Even Vladimir Koslov, chairman of the unregistered opposition party ALGA, stated, "that was a group of other people." The unrest is simply not in the interest of the strikers, because it only provides the grounds for taking action against them by force.
Central Asia expert Arkady Dubnov stated—again, a direct quote—that it cannot be ruled out that parts of the Kazakh opposition living abroad are also involved.
On the other hand, it could suit someone well in the Kazakh capital, Astana, to maintain the tensions.
Ultimately, Kazakhstan’s power elite are already vying for the succession of President Nursultan Nazarbayev.
Quote ends. We had the opportunity to speak with the Kazakh opposition here in Parliament in the presence of the Kazakh ambassador.

The UN Special Representative Miroslav Jentschak announced today that he is impressed by the Kazakh government’s attention to the events of Jana Ozen, and that it is necessary to uncover the true background of the DISTURBANCES.
We should take the Kasharian authorities at their word, measure them by their actions, but avoid reflexive prejudgments.
As I understand it, that is the statement you made today. Yes, the Commission is fighting for the continuation of the food program for the most vulnerable people in the European Union.
She will do everything to present concrete proposals in the foreseeable future regarding a, where the program will be located precisely, and b, how financing will be secured.
I consider this to be urgently necessary and believe that we share a joint responsibility to ensure that this food program actually becomes a reality.
not because I consider it the ultima ratio, but because, from my perspective, it is a signal to show people that we still have a fundamental sense of the necessary solidarity with the

the life situations of people in the European Union who, unfortunately, were unable to participate in a development and who have become the first and greatest victims of the way the European Union has handled the crisis.
I am thinking of Greece, I am thinking of Spain, I am thinking of other countries where precisely what we do as the European Union primarily harms the poorest of the poor.
We are setting a marker, but unfortunately, it is no longer one.
I therefore believe that it is urgently necessary that we not only show consideration for the 18 million people in the European Union who, at this point in time, depend on food being delivered to
are to be made available, but rather that it concerns ensuring we prioritize the fight against poverty – continuing to do so, or indeed initiating it – at the very top of our own agenda.
This signal we have not conveyed thus far.

That, from my perspective, is the decisive point if we want to make further progress here and if we also want to gain the trust of the citizens of our European Union, in order to truly shape a social and solidarity-based Union.
In that sense, you have our support.
We ourselves, dear colleagues, are also called upon to do something to ensure that the governments that have been obstructing progress abandon this stance.
I believe this is also a matter of self-commitment for us.
Esteemed colleague Dohl, I have listened attentively to you.
What you propose – to include a growth assessment for all expenditures in parallel with the subsidiarity review – essentially means narrowing the objectives to growth.
I would like to know from you how you reconcile this with the demands of a Christian Democratic faction, which after all still possesses goals beyond growth.
It is generally known that the economy does not bring children into the world who cannot grow up and who cannot be afforded a life in an intact natural environment.
This therefore indicates that the priorities are being changed by the Commission and also by the Council, that they are being reconsidered.
As a parliamentary group, we will examine very closely whether what you presented this morning truly represents a change in priorities.
Until now, the motto has been: first the economy, which requires functioning financial markets.
And that was initially about stabilizing public finances, that is, reducing debt and calming the markets.
And Mr. Dohl, who is unfortunately not present, I actually wanted to say to him that I would handle it exactly as Georges Marchais would.
I did not, however, understand his response, but I would contradict him.
I believe the measures that were initiated were simply incorrect.
You were not correct. It was not correct to focus solely on the rehabilitation of the economy, while completely disregarding what happened to the people.
It was not right to prioritize the stability of the Euro above all else and to say that what becomes of the people is entirely irrelevant to us.
It must be the other way around. First, it concerns the people, then we can continue discussing Eurozone stabilization.

The speculative attacks on Spain pushed interest rates on Spanish government bonds above 6% and thus close to the level at which other states, such as Greece, Portugal, or indeed Ireland, sought support from the rescue fund.
And the austerity policy, imposed on the member state by the EU, the ECB, and the IMF, with the drastic reductions of public expenditure of all kinds.
Reduction of wages and pensions, increases in value-added tax, and much more have placed the burden on citizens, rather than preventing a renewed spiral.
Stringent cuts in government spending and a deepening recession are driving up states’ debt ratios. And that must be our shared realization.
When Mr. Draghi recently stated that the European social model is at an end, I am pleased, Mr. Barroso, when you say, no, we in the Commission do not think so.
Then I also expect you to go to Greece, to send your people to Greece and to Portugal, to Ireland, and to precisely register what happens there.
What happens to people who are currently struggling to survive?
What happens, or what do we do together, to finally break this spiral of suicide, which has taken hold, particularly in the countries most affected by debt, so that it is interrupted?
It simply cannot be that we stand here idly by.
And we benefit neither from social-political programs that will take effect only when other measures have already proven successful.
We must act now. Where have your objectives from the 2020 strategy to combat poverty gone?
What has become of the European Platform Against Poverty?
It has been set aside.
That was before the crisis.
But now, in the midst of the crisis, people need help, they need support, and they need the action of the European Union.
You do not need empty promises.
We need concrete ideas about what should be done now.
If you do that, you will receive the support of my faction.
Support all those within the Commission who have also recognized the signs of the times and wish to change things.
But please don't simply proceed with the assumption that it will all work out.
Nothing more will come of it if things continue as they are. I urge you to present a concrete project, a concrete program, outlining how we can now actively help the people in the affected countries.
Do something about it.
We will have to do it in our countries so that we are not blocked from having the funds for the ESF 2013 or 2014 through 2020, or indeed for the other programs, reduced.
that the member states fulfill their responsibilities. Thank you.
Esteemed colleagues, the current state of public finances and the economy in Europe leaves no room for a fairytale lecture on tax policy.
The situation within the council is, in fact, quite simple: little progress is made there regarding fiscal policy proposals.
Why?
because some countries are opposed to further tax cooperation,
You benefit from aggressive tax planning. You are tax havens yourselves.
And the contracts explicitly stipulate unanimous agreement on tax matters.
Therefore, the EU Commission has repeatedly suffered failure with its proposals.
They are diluted, they do not progress, as with the interest rate directive. And in newer proposals, nothing ambitious has been suggested at all in anticipatory compliance.

Therefore, Mr. Schimeter, I understand that your job is not easy in this regard. Revise the strategy, propose decisive measures, and then rely on intensified cooperation to end the blocking position in the council.
Mr. President, esteemed colleagues, the present proposal will certainly not prevent state bankruptcy where it should occur.
But doing something is still better than doing nothing at all.
And exceptional situations sometimes require exceptional measures.

The budgetary and debt crisis in some states has led to such an extraordinary situation that important projects and measures within cohesion and structural policy can no longer be implemented, because the banking sector fails as a financier and private investors are no longer available.
An exceptional measure, I consider the present proposal for the creation of risk-sharing instruments to refinance projects in structural policy.
Instruments of cohesion and structural policy available to regions wishing to utilize these compartmentalization tools can be used to provide financial security for ongoing projects.

I am very grateful to the rapporteur, Ms. Danuta Hübner, for her significant contribution to the refinement of the Commission's proposal and for once again clearly outlining when and how these instruments should be utilized.
However, I am also of the opinion that these risk-sharing instruments must be attributable solely to the current situation and cannot constitute a prejudice for the future funding period.
When a change to the biometrics passport regulation was requested, requiring a review after three years and the submission of four studies, our parliamentary group supported this.
And precisely because she had repeatedly voiced significant concerns for data protection law reasons and also due to the overestimation of the benefit of biometric data in passports.

Belief in perfect identification, the overestimation of this means itself, and the consequences that result from it—namely, the underestimation of other links in the security chain—are truly problematic.
The handling of biometric data remains subject to a significant misconception, namely the assumption that it is immutable and the most trustworthy.
And that is quite the opposite.
These data, too, are subject to change over the course of life.
In children, they appear differently than in old age.
And for that very reason, reliable and reputable studies and the conclusions drawn from them are necessary.
Counterfeiting continues apace.
we have now been able to ascertain.
as incidents in Great Britain and other countries repeatedly demonstrate, chips are in no way secure against misuse.
They are cheerfully cracked and can mean permanent damage for those affected.
Even the standards within the EU are extraordinarily varied.
The error rate is, as in France and the Netherlands, very, very high.
And again and again, the question must be posed: what benefit do biometric data offer us if documents are forged and circulating?
Therefore, if a link in the chain is forged, if the originating documents are inconsistent, biometric data should not assist us further.
One last thing. The Chaos Computer Club in Germany needed only a few minutes to demonstrate a forgery.

For this, the friends from the Chaos Computer Club needed the lid of a plastic bottle, superglue, a digital camera, and a little wood glue. In just a few minutes, they had cracked the chip. So much for the supposed security.
We expect the Commission to submit the studies, and of course, also the results and the consequences that can be derived from them. Thank you.
Esteemed Council, the Commission is unfortunately not as adequately represented today as I would have wished, out of respect for the Parliament.

As a Member of Parliament from a region that will be significantly impacted by the planned changes, namely the Eifel, a question compels itself upon me after careful observation of the debate: whether the unfortunately rather inadequate attempt,

whether a standardization of criteria for disadvantaged areas truly addresses the needs in these regions. Especially as the necessary information for a meaningful and responsible decision is not currently available.
Above all, I wonder whether a sufficiently thorough impact assessment was truly conducted.
To do justice to farmers, we need not only biophysical criteria, but also socioeconomic criteria,

And therefore, I urge the Commission to reconsider this important aspect with the necessary time, independently of the overall package of the CAP reform, and above all after the presentation of the necessary documents and a careful analysis of the implications regarding the criteria.

I do, in fact, believe that we must also work, in cooperation with the asylum support office and the Greek authorities, to identify more quickly which individuals who have arrived in Greece may actually be eligible to apply for asylum.

can also be transferred to other countries of the European Union, because firstly, they can definitively never return to their home country, and secondly, they may also possess potential and qualifications that can be meaningful and productive for all.
Essentially, however, it is also about assisting the Greeks in facilitating registration and identification processes more quickly, to expedite aid delivery, but also

to return those individuals to their home countries who neither possess the qualifications nor the authorization to remain in Greece or the European Union, because they would actually have had the opportunity to stay in their own countries of origin.
Thank you, Mr. President, Mr. Minister, Ms. Commissioner. Thank you also to the rapporteur for her consistently dedicated and exemplary work.
Much of the criticism that Sophie Infeld has voiced, I can share, support, or have partially supported.
yet there invariably comes a point at which one must assume responsibility.
And for the EPP, or indeed for myself, I therefore also maintain that we must now address the realities and cannot retreat to ideological or theoretical positions.
The fact is, the USA have been collecting this PNR data for ten years, and there hasn't been a single complaint.
The fact is that we all don’t want to be in a position where, even with a negative stance, we can halt data traffic altogether.
You had just done that.
It is also a fact that we do not want air traffic between Europe and the USA to cease.
And the fact is that the United States has a right to know who is entering its country.
And my assessment is also that the legal services have verbally stated to all of us that this agreement is better than the other agreement, than the alternatives.
Therefore, one must also take responsibility here.
and for this we were also elected.
Responsibility for citizens who would otherwise be left alone and with fewer protections and rights.
Responsibility for airlines, which, as the investigating commissioner had also pointed out, would otherwise be left in absolute legal uncertainty.
Responsibility, however, also for the EU as a contracting party in matters of data protection and security, and also responsibility for a balanced relationship between security and data protection.
Therefore, we are, in sum, also inclined to approve of this agreement, even taking into account that it is not perfect, but precisely because of its consequences.
And if one wishes to better protect citizens and if one also wishes to provide citizens with better data protection, one assumes responsibility here as well and approves this agreement. Thank you.
Thank you, Mr. President. Thank you, Mr. Commissioner. Those were insightful remarks you have given us.
Thank you very much for that.

Numbers sometimes say more than grand words, and to this day, the European Parliament—as you also mentioned—and the European Patent Office have granted almost 2000 patents on plants and nearly 1200 patents on animals, originating both with and without the use of genetic engineering.
I may mention two outstanding examples. The granting of patents on genetically modified and conventionally bred barley. This applies to the entire chain from seed to plant.
Consequently, our farmers, as well as our brewers, producers, and indeed we consumers are affected.
And this example, in my opinion, demonstrates a devastating extent of patenting.
Second example, the so-called long-life tomato. Not to be confused with your long-life oil, which you have in your diesel engines.
With this tactic employed by the applying US corporation Arcadia, this patent was obtained in disregard of valid EU regulations.
It is not the tomato that has been patented, but its genetic material, namely selected enzymes.

This demonstrates the tactics being employed here. And that, as you said, Mr. Commissioner, despite the fact that, according to Article 4 CLIP of the 1998 Biopatent Directive, plant varieties and animal breeds, and a and b, essentially biological procedures for breeding plants or animals, are not patentable.
We are of the opinion that this definition must be clarified; it must be interpreted more precisely.
Technical procedures used to support conventional breeding must not lead to patentability in general.
We are not claiming a patent on life, specifically.
And we need a clear signal here for greater ethics and greater honesty in our dealings with creation, once again against patenting life in all of Europe.
Therefore, Commissioner, we demand a clear statement from the Commission that patents on breeding material and genetic resources are prohibited in Europe and will remain so.
Secondly, we demand a clear position on Article 4 of the Biopatent Directive. No patents on life.

And thirdly, Mr. Commissioner, we demand, on behalf of many farmers and breeders in Europe, a clear and unambiguous codification of the breeder's and farmer's privilege throughout all legislation. Thank you very much.
Thank you, Madam Chair. I would like to address the discharge of Europol and Eurojust.
Regarding Europol. There is little to no fault to be found.
The annual financial statements accurately reflect the financial situation as of 2010 in all material respects, and all underlying transactions comply with regulations and are therefore also lawful.
Notably, the high overheads are striking in relation to the overall, actually low accumulated costs.
Europol attributes this to the relocation to a new headquarters. That is, of course, understandable.
However, Europol has pledged to take further measures in the future to avoid such high transfers.
Furthermore, Europol intends to commit to monthly monitoring of the budget’s execution from 2012 onwards.
I recommend that we follow up on this to ensure it actually happens.
Against this backdrop, I recommend relieving the burden on Europol.
Regarding Eurojust. Here, the annual financial statement reflects the financial situation in 2010 in all material respects.
All transactions are also lawful and compliant here.
But high operating expenses were also carried over to the year 2011.
Following Eurojust’s justification, this was primarily due to an organizational structure project, a new computer infrastructure, and costs associated with data processing.
It is announced that everything will be improved in the future, including better adherence to tender requirements.
I also recommend that we review this in the future and, above all, verify whether all open positions will indeed be filled in the future.
That has been improved.
But if these positions are not filled soon, then we will almost have to consider cutting funds, which would be detrimental to Orius.
I still recommend relief. Thank you.
Madam President, esteemed Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, what must alarm us, what must induce panic, is not the sheer number of young unemployed people in Europe alone, but the development.
From 2008 to 2011, the number of young unemployed individuals increased by 26.5 percent. This is stated by the International Labour Organization.
It is this development that urgently requires action. We are not only disconnecting an entire generation from the labor market, we are disconnecting an entire generation from a future worth living.
If we give young people the feeling of absolute uselessness, we should not be surprised that they turn away from this EU, because they lack reasonable employment and life prospects.

Sir Inspector, I urgently request that you ensure decisive countermeasures are initiated. I already recognize certain aspects, but please ensure that this long period of intellectual stagnation does not devolve into operational frenzy.

When I read that the Commission is launching a program whereby young people, when applying abroad, are now to receive financial support, then we are organizing a traveling circus that does not solve the problem.
Conversely, it will prove counterproductive. Technicians, doctors, engineers, and nursing staff will then be poached from states that are wealthier, those not experiencing this crisis.
Now, in this crisis, it requires identifying the cause of this development. Offensive measures, namely the reduction of this austerity policy that is hampering the economy in Europe,
We need a targeted growth policy, we need a strengthening of domestic purchasing power, public investment in education, research, and alternative energies.
that would be the way
With the combination of European funding, it would then be possible to develop an integrated concept that creates a life perspective for young people.
Final Remark. This youth unemployment also does not tolerate the nonsense of wanting to raise the retirement age for people to 70.
We need a different policy that provides young people with access to the labor market.
Therefore, I earnestly request it. Thank you.
Colleague, you have just stated that everything in favor of a financial transaction tax would be speculation, and yet you have come forward with highly speculative examples yourselves.

I would like to know from you, in light of what you have said, what you then think of these investigations of the Commission and the Study Commission, which very, very clearly state that, to date, far too little consideration has been given to the real economy in its dependence on

to the financial markets, that is to say, that 95% of companies are in no way dependent on this for raising capital, and that one can indeed turn a negative growth effect, which has been discussed until now, into a positive one by allocating appropriate growth-promoting public investment.
Is this also merely speculation for you, or would you say that such a well-founded, comprehensive study by the Commission has its justification and represents a strong argument?

Thank you. Yes, colleagues, the financial transaction tax is certainly not identical to the Tobin tax, which has been discussed and debated for many years, but I believe it incorporates essential elements of the Tobin tax.
She does, at the very least, consider the idea of involving the financial markets in taxation, of taxing them, and above all, of having them contribute to the costs of the crisis.
I believe that is a very important signal to the financial markets,
That is also a very important signal to citizens, to our voters.
There were numerous actions in a considerable number of member states—petitions, written appeals to politicians—to finally introduce a financial transaction tax at the European level.
I believe that the parliament, with the majority that is emerging here for this report, for this tax, has achieved a significant success.
Certainly, this is not sufficient to stabilize and curtail the financial markets as perhaps would be necessary. But I believe it is a truly important step that has been taken here.
And I would like to expressly appeal to the council to take the voices of citizens and voters seriously and to advocate for,
that a genuine introduction takes place, that the introduction of this tax is not blocked in the council due to the British position or other positions.
I believe it is clear that the citizens of the European Union want this tax, and I believe it is a great responsibility within the

It now lies in the Council's hands to act here. And I would like to use my allotted time to appeal to the Council to do everything possible to ensure that this tax is now actually implemented and becomes a reality. Thank you.
Dear colleagues, I believe that amidst all the detailed issues we can discuss and which still need to be discussed in the further legislative process, we should agree on one thing:
Be clear. Financial markets cannot function according to the model whereby banks pocket the profits when everything goes well, but taxpayers foot the bill when something goes wrong.
And therefore, it makes sense to also subject financial transactions to taxation.
And it makes sense to do so across borders.

In Europe, or at least in the Eurozone, we will not experience disruptions, but rather we will consistently contribute to establishing a stable financial center that generates what financial centers are actually intended for: namely, that companies pay.

Access to capital means that savers have the opportunity to put something aside or to set something aside for retirement, and that financial markets thus fulfill the task for which they were originally created, namely to provide added value for the real economy.
All of that which drove us into the financial crisis were products that did not create value for the real economy.

And therefore, it makes sense to contribute to ensuring that this is heavily penalized, that it is sanctioned, that it is regulated, in the sense that capital once again fulfills its purpose, through taxation.
And for that reason, I advocate for this proposal with a clear majority today.
The reform of the general preference system was undoubtedly necessary.
It is now beneficial that there are longer durations and that there is greater security for exporters.
However, the criteria are too imprecise, as the development committee has already stated.
The commission unfortunately refers only to World Bank classifications.
In this regard, Parliament has repeatedly and critically examined gross domestic product as the sole criterion in the past.
The definition of upper-middle-income countries can refer to countries with a Gross National Income of 4,000 or up to 12,000 dollars.
That is, therefore, a vast and far too broad range. And it does not do justice to the realities on the ground in any way.
That countries like Saudi Arabia and Kuwait are eliminated, we certainly do not find concerning.
The reform in that direction was therefore positive.
But these countries are high-income countries, anyway.
Russia and China are countries against which, however, with elevated middle incomes. Regarding their potential withdrawal from the APS, we certainly need not worry about that.
But this category of countries also includes much poorer countries, such as Namibia and Ecuador.
Previously, the Commission had also at least considered the vulnerability criterion. Namely, countries that export little or only a very limited range of goods.
This at least helps to prevent countries that are less dependent on the export of few products and therefore particularly vulnerable from being rated too highly.
Why, then, did the Commission remove this criterion?
Countries such as the Dominican Republic, Fiji, Gabon, and Botswana will thus be excluded, even though their economies fall under the criterion of vulnerability.
Why did the commission not continue with the existing criteria, which were already somewhat inadequate?
The suspicion arises that the Commission intends to force poorer countries into free trade agreements that are disadvantageous to them.

The preference system, however, is an instrument for promoting development and cannot be replaced by pure trade instruments, in which the development path of a country or region no longer plays a role whatsoever.
Fortunately, however, colleagues in the plenary session will still have the opportunity to support our amendment, which incorporates vulnerability as a criterion.
The new regulation also results in trade regions being fragmented.
Neighboring countries in customs unions will soon have to adhere to different rules when exporting to the EU.
That has nothing to do with our goal of regional integration.
And the Commission should, instead of individual countries, increasingly consider development regions.
Here too, we Greens have submitted an amendment that we hope will garner widespread support.
And it is also problematic when countries that yesterday still benefited from the APS are to be excluded from the program overnight.
Transition periods are necessary, and that a few months are insufficient for economic development, we see in our own countries.

Ultimately, we, as members of parliament, must also consider whether, in all legislative proposals, we want to focus solely on speed and then work with skewed compromises, or whether we would prefer to involve the entire assembly.

I believe that the entire parliament is important for legislation, and also for democracy. And it is not time or speed that are important, but rather time is needed to establish democracy and to properly enact laws. Thank you.

Thank you, Mr. President, High Representative. I, too, was a member of the European Parliament’s observation mission in the Democratic Republic of Congo and was able to observe the hope and expectation for a better future with which people queued and waited at polling stations to cast their votes.
We know today that these expectations were not fulfilled.
Although the Democratic Republic of the Congo calls itself democratic, these elections were neither fair nor democratic.
We must address this proactively, as Ms. Nedeljewa also did in her report.
The previous president, Yusuf Kabila, declared himself the election winner. The opposition is being suppressed.
In the east of the country, violent clashes between government troops and so-called rebels have flared up again, and whether third states, such as Rwanda, are involved remains unclear.
The suffering party, in any case, is the civilian population, which has not been able to live in peace and quiet for decades.
The country's wealth is squandered in a swamp of corruption. The Congo remains, in all assessments at the international level, among the last ranked.

The international community of states, particularly the European Union with its capabilities, must increase the pressure on the President of the Republic of the Congo to allow genuine democracy in his country. He has an opportunity at the next regional elections.

to that end, and that the Congolese army not only ceases to harass the civilian population, but also apprehends and hands over to a court internationally wanted criminals against humanity such as Bosko and Ndanganga.
Internationally, all states should finally commit to supplying no further weapons to the Congo.
Without external pressure, human suffering and poverty in this country will not end.
Colleagues, the Tupac proposal aims to establish further intervention powers against crisis countries within the Eurozone.
The European Semester, established as a framework for necessary and improved coordination of financial and economic policy, is to be given teeth.
According to the Commission’s intention, Member States should be able to be compelled to accept financial assistance.
The Six-Pack has already established extensive sanctioning possibilities that can be imposed on Eurozone states facing financial difficulties.
The European Semester is already perceived by citizens more as a reduction in democracy than as a sensible instrument for economic policy coordination.
Simultaneously, the German government is openly threatening Greek citizens with expulsion from the Eurozone should they make the wrong decision in Sunday’s election.
Why do we not cease these degrading and undemocratic displays of menace?
In a situation where the Euro crisis has once again escalated dramatically—I think of Spain, of Cyprus—it does us no good to put member states already struggling in the crisis on display.
We should finally develop solutions. The rapporteurs of TUPEX have indeed developed meaningful approaches to that end.
Elisa Ferreira’s reference to the redemption fund was, indeed, quite pertinent. That would be a worthwhile and sensible measure to combat debt.
but also Jean-Paul Gauzet's proposal for an orderly sovereign default.
Central, however, is that Europe is undertaking a joint and concerted effort to put the Eurozone back on a path of growth.
The stronger nations in Europe must cease to be self-satisfied and point fingers at their partner countries.
You must begin doing your homework and investing in growth, and taking responsibility.
The one-sided austerity policy à la Merkel has simply failed as a solution to the crisis.

Thank you, Mr. Chairman, esteemed Commissioner, dear colleagues. In June 2010, the heads of state and government of the EU finally recognized the need for a more coordinated economic and financial policy within the European Community.
At the summit, they essentially invented the European Semester.
It is indeed entirely correct that members of an Economic and Monetary Union must not solely focus on how their policies affect businesses, employees, and consumers within their own country.
A European perspective is necessary.

An internal market without coordination in economic, wage, and social policy presents the member states with a significant temptation: to create short-term growth and jobs at the expense of their neighbors.
Such imbalances can lead to the economic and political disintegration of the currency union.
And the EU is currently facing precisely such a situation.

The German economy has drained its neighbors dry for years, offering no stimulus through investment and wage growth. Instead, Berlin has nearly driven the Eurozone to ruin with a decade of aggressive export policy.

Therefore, it is encouraging that the Commission is now gradually getting to the heart of this core problem of the Euro crisis in its country-specific recommendations and making corresponding proposals.

Quite rightly, the Federal Republic is being called upon to invest more in education, research, and childcare. And quite rightly, the Commission is being called upon to stop the abuse of mini-jobs and to align wage growth with productivity growth.
This is a late, but important realization.
And I hope, Commissioner Rehn, that you vigorously advocate for this demand vis-à-vis the German government, even if there is no formal procedure for surplus countries.

Mr. Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, colleagues. Firstly, I would like to express my gratitude to the Commission, particularly Commissioner Barnier. For a very simple reason: the experience from the previous legislative period, the one prior to 2009, was

was that, with the exception of a very brief moment of awakening when the proposal of the European Private Company came about—the predecessor of Mr. Commissioner Barnier, Mr. Commissioner McCreevy—corporate law had essentially been slumbering deeply. And that we, during these five years of this important matter, which is also significant for the single market, had failed to address it.
have progressed.
Thank goodness, that has changed fundamentally.

Meanwhile, there are a variety of consultation documents from the European Commission, and an expert group has been established to address the question of further developing company law. We now have a very current consultation, which, as Parliament, we are naturally also addressing.

The Legal Committee has decided that we do not want to do this in the form of a report. And that is simply because a report would still require additional time and, of course, be somewhat more detailed.

We have chosen the means of an oral question to the Commission in order to be able to discuss this topic with the Commission, with Commissioner Barnier, and simultaneously to clearly define our position as Parliament in a subsequent resolution regarding what should happen next.
I believe that it is necessary, similarly to what we have experienced before, approximately ten years ago, to develop a new action plan for European social law. And that for a variety of reasons.
There are gaps within European social law. Genuine gaps that fundamentally result in the internal market not being established.
I want to cite the example of the absence of the 14th Relocation Directive. Most cases have demonstrated it as a typical example of such a gap.
The Parliament has called for this twice in the legislative reports, that concrete proposals from the European Commission be put forward.
There is also the expert group, which the European Commission itself appointed, that has likewise expressed the same opinion on the matter.
It simply belongs to the fundamental freedoms within the internal market that a company must also be able to move within the internal market with regard to its registered seat.
This possibility does not exist today, or only under extremely difficult conditions.

Against this backdrop, I must also simultaneously criticize the fact that the European Commission’s previous response to Directive 14 actually falls significantly short of Parliament’s expectations and, in our view, does not meet the standard of a qualified response to a legislative initiative.
But we are optimistic that, within the scope of the further work, should an action plan materialize, this proposal will hopefully be included in the action plan after all.
