Another important point in corporate law is the question of the further development of corporate law with the aim of reducing burdens for businesses.
We already have very concrete proposals from the Commission on the table, for example, regarding competition.
But I believe that, beyond this, there is also more to do and further aspects that will now also be clarified within the scope of the consultation.
Here, we also anticipate further proposals from the Commission.
I would also like to ask the commission to revive the topic of European private companies, which is currently stalled in the Council.

If there are individual member states—and I may express my personal opinion here—if there are individual member states within the EU that, due to a lack of their own decisiveness, are not able to resolve this deadlock on their own,

To advance Europe, one must, as with other initiatives such as patents or family law, occasionally consider utilizing the instrument of enhanced cooperation, so that at least all other Europeans have the opportunity to benefit from this possibility.
And I would ask the Commission to reconsider this matter with particular emphasis.
Another open issue is the question of applicable law, that is, a kind of Rome Regulation for cross-border issues in corporate law.
I also maintain that this question requires further investigation and discussion and would request that the commission undertake this task.
with this, too, stands in close connection.
insolvency law, but there is already an announcement that we will receive a concrete proposal from the European Commission within a foreseeable timeframe.
You see, there is an enormous amount to be done in corporate law.

I am grateful that Commissioner Barnier has once again taken the initiative, and that it is apparent that we will receive significant proposals in the second half of this legislative term, which can then represent progress in shaping the single market.
The parliament supports this in principle and in approach.
The details, of course, will be discussed further. We will certainly do so.
But therefore, thanks to the commission.
And now, we would naturally be pleased if the Commission were to actually take up our initiatives and transform them into concrete proposals. Thank you.
Dear Commissioner, I greatly appreciate your proposal regarding performance-related pay policy.
But when it came to the minimum wage, you reneged on your commitment to Mrs. Merkel. And the matter of employment creation in the healthcare sector – I don’t believe you.
How can new work possibly be created there when the Commission has already compelled southern and eastern member states to reduce their hospital capacities by as much as half?

How can employment in the healthcare sector possibly arise when, in the new state-specific recommendations for the European Semester, the Commission is compelling some member states to further reduce spending on health?
I fear this point in this plan is pure announcement policy, not a genuine initiative for new work.
On the contrary, even today, due to austerity measures, there is a shortage of medical supplies and medication not only in Greece.

I believe that whoever consistently establishes new rescue umbrellas for banks must now focus on a rescue umbrella for the people, particularly for ensuring medical care in crisis-stricken countries. Thank you.
Yes, thank you. The mood among countless pro-Europeans like myself is one of frightened dismay over what is currently happening in Europe.
It is, at the very least, gratifying that what we are dealing with is now stated much more clearly, and that the eyes are not closed even regarding Italy.

You are well aware that you are trapped in a series of pitfalls, not only those of debt and growth, but also those of trust and the trap of power. Esteemed Commission, and addressed to the Council as well.
You have, unfortunately, so far failed to address the central question, the separation of the financial sector from the real economy.
Everything we have decided here will, according to expert opinion, be repeatedly assessed as the shadow banking sector continues to lack serious limitations.
Furthermore, we are also dealing with systemic risks. Furthermore, the question of "Too Big to Fail" has not been adequately addressed, and there is little point in discussing the rating agencies.

I can only urge you and advise you, as you now work towards the European Council meeting, to restore credibility in Europe by seriously addressing this power dynamic between the real and financial economies.
To put it concisely, that they are finally working credibly before Europeans to ensure that banks are held accountable and that citizens do not always bear the burden.

Dear Colleague Fehrmann, you come from a country that rejected the euro, albeit primarily on the grounds that it wishes to retain the flexibility of devaluation, particularly for social policy reasons.

In light of the experiences you have now had in Sweden, would you recommend to the Greeks as well to leave the Eurozone in order to be able to actively utilize this socioeconomic instrument of devaluations accordingly?
Yes, thank you very much, Mr. President. I would also like to extend my sincere thanks to the shadow rapporteurs and to the rapporteur.
We passed this report in the Environmental Committee with a substantial majority, by a vote of 62 to 0, with no abstentions.
That demonstrates that we are actually very, very closely aligned there, even regarding compromises.

And naturally, the highest priority in these legislative procedures must be a high level of protection, strong consumer protection, particularly for the most vulnerable members of our society, for children in need of protection.
Regarding gluten intolerance, this is a problem. And specifically, also in kindergarten.
Looking around, I have two children of this age, and considering the allergies and intolerances that prevail there, I believe we made the right decision.
And we should then also discuss this together in the second reading, with advice, with the committee.
And I believe that we will also arrive at a good result.
Thank you very much. A report on a traffic accident over the weekend involving a truck driver who fell asleep due to exhaustion and drove into the ditch has once again confirmed for me how necessary
a clear and consistent regulation of driving and rest times and their control through a digital tachograph is essential—for us, for traffic safety, but also for those affected themselves.
The digital tachograph represents a degree of innovation. It presents new problems, but also retains older ones.
The new problems arise from new opportunities for manipulation, which we must also master technically.
The old problems are those that we can observe, so to speak, during or due to a lack of control in various member states.
What we are now regulating must be considered significantly. Firstly, that not every time a journey is not recorded, a rest period automatically ensues.
for many drivers must load and unload, and this is, of course, also to be considered working time.
The second problem is that the speed records have been removed from the file.
I consider that to be incorrect, as there are also significant accident risks here.
We would also like to have weight sensors and we would also like to have a hotline so that fraud can be reported, anonymously and tracked.
What I will also propose is that animal transport controls be included in this regulation.
I consider this important, because this too is a central element of our legislation.

Madam President, many thousands of people could still be alive today or would not suffer from permanent disabilities had professional medical assistance been provided quickly enough, that is within the first so-called golden hour, following their accident.
We would be a good deal closer to Vision Zero.
Well, the eCall system, about which we are speaking today, cannot prevent accidents. It also does not absolve one of the initial duty to provide assistance.
It serves solely to automatically inform an emergency call center in the event of a serious accident.
This must, also in order to avoid misuse and overload due to minor accidents, establish verbal contact with the vehicle involved in the accident.
Only once the emergency call has been confirmed or no one responds will emergency physicians, equipped with a few but life-saving pieces of information about the accident site, be dispatched.
Responsibility for the functioning of this rescue chain rests subsidiarily with the Member States.
As long as the sensors installed in the vehicle do not detect an accident, the eCall system remains inactive, transmitting no signals or data and being untraceable.
It is, therefore, also considerably superior from a data protection perspective to a mobile telephone.
The system only becomes active with automatic activation controlled by sensors, or with deliberate manual triggering.
It then transmits a pre-agreed minimal dataset of information to a rescue coordination center.
Across Europe, uniform standards and specifications will ensure that these data are recognized, assessed, and processed upon arrival as emergency calls.
Therefore, the Member States must also upgrade and expand their emergency response systems accordingly.

We want this eCall emergency call system to be based on the EU-wide emergency number 112, to be free of charge for the user, to function everywhere in the EU, and to be compatible with the emergency call systems of neighboring third countries.
It should be based on an interoperable technology, a neutral, open system architecture.
These can also later support other intelligent public transport services, such as real-time traffic information or parking availability.
In recognition of the automotive industry’s significant achievements in providing private emergency call systems, these should retain their validity alongside the public 112 eCall.
Users can also decide in favor of such a system based on comprehensive information.
This may be accompanied by costs, if necessary.
Use of the data by workshops, insurance companies, towing services, or other service providers
A small village in Franconia is known for its good beer. This rhyme points to a small problem that we have created for ourselves today.

For if this brewery or beverage distributor is 107 kilometers from my place of residence, I no longer have a chance that he will continue to offer me his goods in the future without having to purchase a new tachograph, without incurring new bureaucracy.

And therefore, dear colleagues, I voted against this resolution today. Because I am of the opinion that we should not place too much of a burden on our small and medium-sized enterprises. There were many points that we were able to incorporate, which were positive, thank God.
They were, after all, planned to accept only distances of up to 50 kilometers within the service area of a regional provider.
That was utterly absurd on the part of the EU Commission.
Something like 100 kilometers, perhaps, is still just about feasible.
But what if it extends beyond that?
Also, I find it excessive.
And as a final point, representing a workers’ organization within the CSU, I would also like to say: We are establishing with this regulation complete oversight of employees.
Why?
Because, for example, the person who is responsible for construction or for beverages, for breweries, offers his goods and is completely monitored throughout the entire workday via GPS.
Therefore, I also consider what we have decided today highly questionable, for data protection reasons, and I reiterate why I voted against it.
Yes, thank you very much for this question.
Why I am not waiting for this decision,
I awaited the approval of the European People's Party in the Legal Affairs Committee, as we raised the necessary questions concerning the legal certainty of ACTA during the process itself.
And there was silence in the forest and refusal.
That is what they did not want. Now it is obvious that the ECJ is to be used to cause a delay. That is clear.
Why I mentioned the broad scope for interpretation,
Because, as you have asked two questions, I must answer both of them; that is unfortunately the case.
because one can extract and interpret the monitoring of the internet, auxiliary police officers, ISPs, and everything else from these extensive formulations.
And that means legal uncertainty. Legal uncertainty also does not help our economy, dear colleagues.
Mr. Leichtfried, may I ask you, are you in favor of discussing the modernization of copyright at the European level?
or are they entirely opposed to the rejection of any intellectual property.
And how do you envision the e-commerce directive being adapted to modern circumstances in the future?
From your statement, I gather that you reject a discussion about these matters altogether and do not uphold intellectual property.
Is that correct, or how should I view it?
Yes, thank you. This is not about individual facts that we need to discuss, but rather the fundamental question of how we approach democracy and fundamental rights.
And when we examine the records, we find that they essentially symbolize a lack of transparency, a deficit of democracy, and a violation of fundamental rights, because they were devised in secret.
and, in a way, undemocratic, because the free use of the internet simply might no longer be possible afterward, and neither could the freedom to utilize generic products to the extent as before.
These are the reasons why millions of people have taken to the streets and the vote on ACTA has long since taken place.
Yes, a vote on ACTA has taken place, on the streets, online, regarding the petitions committee, in a great many countries, not only within the EU, but also in the EU.
also outside the EU. And I believe we must not ignore this vote. It is a vote of direct democracy by many citizens who have elected us.
I can only tell you to file the records away, put them in the archives; that would be proper.

Madam President, as rapporteur for the Committee on Budgets and the Committee on Budgetary Control, I have concluded two procedures under your presidency: the budgetary rules, which establish a framework for the coming MFF period, and the OLAV procedure.
Since November 2008, this regulation has been pending in the Council, and you have brought this procedure to completion based on the results of the Polish presidency.
I would like to thank you, therefore, for two truly very, very dedicated civil servants who processed these dossiers and also brought them to the attention of the Ambassador.
They will be missed, his efficiency as a negotiator will be missed.
You have truly earned the financial interests of the European Union.
Thank you very much.
Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen, I am speaking here as a representative of my parliamentary group and would like to support the motion put forward by Colleague Fjellner.
Ladies and gentlemen, we do not have many raw materials in Europe.
The raw material we have here is our brain and our creativity.
This necessitates careful handling of the subject of intellectual property rights.
The European Commission has submitted this proposal, which it has put forward to us, to the Court of Justice of the European Union for an opinion to clarify still-open questions.
I believe that respect for the highest court of the European Union alone dictates that we await this decision.
There is objectively no reason whatsoever to make this decision today.
No one will be prevented from voting against it once the court has presented its decision and its opinion.
But the decision that is then made occurs within a different awareness, a different understanding than today's.
I do not mean that those driving on the wrong side of the road on the internet highway should dictate our policy. And therefore, my request is to support this proposal. Thank you.
As always, when colleague Turmes speaks, it is very insightful, and one wishes that what he says had much more influence on European policy.
I wanted to follow up on that.
Naturally, these project bonds are a sensible undertaking, but only if they are sustainability-oriented and if the necessary political groundwork is established for them.
We risk insuring risks with guarantees that we cannot politically control.

Specifically, the energy transition in Germany would require a 3,800-kilometer grid network; only 100 kilometers of these corresponding high-voltage transmission lines have been built, partly due to resistance from the public – notably, environmentally conscious citizens.
We need some input from policymakers on this.

One idea would be to create shared TEN-Corridors, meaning not only to combine high-speed rail lines and broadband networks, but also to construct the corresponding cable networks above them, perhaps alongside the highway.
That requires, however, a much more comprehensive planning than has been foreseen thus far, but I would like to at least suggest this here.

Dear colleagues, I consider Schengen to be one of the greatest achievements within the European Union. However, I am also aware that national borders are and will always remain a very sensitive issue for our member states.
I am aware that the problems existing between member states regarding Schengen cannot simply be ignored.
And there exist various problems.
And by ignoring, one does not make the problems better, nor does one solve them better.
I live on the border with the Czech Republic, and here, no one would ever consider wanting to close the border again, simply because we are experiencing problems.
But I also ask the Commission for support in this area, and not for restriction or correction.
Covert surveillance has been established because we want to guarantee security while simultaneously upholding freedom of movement.
And if we conduct successful border surveillance, specifically in areas bordering the Czech Republic, where one or more drug dealers – not just in a few instances, but in many –
I believe it would be beneficial if the German Federal Minister of the Interior and his Czech counterpart were to meet in order to jointly resolve the issues that exist at the border.
And that is something the Commission should not influence through regulation, but rather positively and supportively.

We want to curb the populists but resolve the real problems together. Therefore, I also ask the Council to work with the Parliament to find a solution that allows us to successfully adopt the Schengen dossiers, so that we have freedom of movement while simultaneously guaranteeing the security of citizens.
Thank you. The instances of disproportionate border controls listed by the Parliament in its question also demonstrate why the Council wishes to exclude the Parliament from Schengen in principle.
The Council intends, in fact, to continue undermining freedom of movement without involving Parliament, without any form of parliamentary oversight, without any form of public scrutiny.
No wonder, then, that you prefer to pat yourselves on the back in back rooms, far from uncomfortable questions.

No wonder the German government wants to rule out an evaluation of the internal borders entirely without conducting an evaluation itself, and therefore does not want to examine to what extent freedom of movement is being restricted.
Schengen does not belong to the governments, but to the people of Europe, and therefore also belongs within the European Parliament. Thank you.

Dear President of the Council of the European Union, dear Dimitris Christofias, it is a special moment for me and my group today to be able to welcome you here in your capacity as President of the Council of the European Union.
And we are also pleased that, for the first time in the history of the European Union, a person at the head of the EU stands there whom we can count among our political family.
You assume the presidency at a time when the European Union faces immense challenges. And it is now necessary to set the course for whether the European
Whether the union will actually have a future, or whether it will prove to be a footnote in history—which, from my perspective, would be a historical defeat.
Following the conversations we have had with you, with representatives of your government, with the chairs of factions and parties in your country, I know that you are committed to this
have prepared the presidency excellently and that you are also aware of the magnitude of your responsibilities.
However, and as you have clearly demonstrated today, you deliberately want to draw the attention of those in power to the living conditions of the people.
And I can tell you here, after everything I have heard in recent years, that it is the first time a President of the European Union has actually done and announced and said precisely this tone.
I have long missed hearing it stated in official speeches that this is about the people, about those who are not responsible for the crisis yet bear the brunt of its consequences.
It will be difficult to implement precisely this approach.
I believe that a great deal would already be gained, and I am very certain you will do so, if you primarily encourage people, with your presidency and as you express it,
to exercise the right to advocate for their rights and to contribute to ensuring that the Council and the European institutions are fully aware of this task.
We repeatedly discuss the euro and its stability, the necessity of which, I also see, is vital for the functioning of the European Union and the Eurozone.
But that is an instrument.
There were political conditions for this, which have been defined.

It can never be the aim of the European Union to accept that people within the European Union must suffer from hunger, that healthcare systems collapse, or that local authorities are forced to cease their operations.
Something has gone amiss here.
It is not what we can designate as the goal of the European Union.
I strongly support your demand that it concerns social cohesion, solidarity between the individual member states, but also between the most diverse population groups.
And the European Union must not simply allow itself to be used as an instrument or as a spokesperson for a small, specific stratum of the population, nor present itself as such.

And one final point I would also like to address, naturally, to emphasize that everything you have also mentioned in your priorities is important to us, and that we will support the points, as I have just defined them, that move in that direction.
Please do something to ensure that people no longer live in fear.
Fear is the worst advisor for democracies.
And I think that some decisions in recent weeks and months, particularly in the elections in Greece and the votes on the referendum in Ireland, were also influenced by fear.
And if the governing bodies of the European Union contribute to people being afraid to make their own free decisions, then that is not a good sign for the future of the European Union.
Best of success in your work!
Colleagues, I believe we have a very important responsibility here, also as co-rapporteurs working together.
It will be of great, considerable importance to the colleague to work swiftly and reliably on this dossier in the coming weeks and months.

Eyes are currently fixed on us and on the Council, regarding this matter, to overcome the banking crisis in Europe through a further step of European integration, namely through a European Banking Union.
It must be said that Parliament already demanded this two years ago with a broad majority.
We have conducted 26 trilogues.
We have taken a step in that direction, but unfortunately not as far as would actually have been necessary.
Further billion-euro invoices have resulted from this.
It is positive that the Council has now drawn the necessary conclusions and intends to further deepen this step for the Eurozone.
And it is commendable that the Commission has prepared the proposals so quickly.
The decision of the Council that the ECB should become the location of the Eurozone supervisor is, however, associated with some difficulties.
In the council, this leads to unanimity and results in the Parliament not having a shared decision-making role in this dossier.
After the experiences with the supervisory package, this is unacceptable.

And therefore, it is important that we work swiftly here, but also negotiate this proposal for changes at the ECB with the necessary adjustments to the existing supervisory regime as a package, thereby establishing, in effect, the principle of parliamentary democratic participation.
Democratically, there are further challenges as well.
The ECB is independent in monetary policy, but not in fiscal policy, for which it has not previously had any tasks.

If she assumes responsibility within banking supervision, Parliament needs full budgetary powers, full oversight powers, the right to question, and appointment powers; and I am certain that Parliament will assert these in a broad majority.

The complex questions, moreover, regarding the internal market, consumer protection, and the balance between European power and financial responsibility, we will have to discuss thoroughly in the coming weeks. Thank you.
Thank you. With the proposal to exclude developing countries from preferential market access, the Commission is attempting to push these countries into free trade agreements.
These agreements, despite being termed "economic partnerships," do not concern themselves with the interests of the partner countries, but solely with those of the EU.
That runs completely counter to the EU’s goal of reducing poverty and aligning all external policy instruments with it.
Countries such as Cameroon, Côte d'Ivoire, and Namibia would be massively affected by this restriction.
Regional integration projects, such as those in Southeast Africa, would collapse if Kenya were to enter into such an agreement.
South-South cooperation would be at an end.
We cannot advocate for free trade globally and simultaneously suggest that other countries should kindly purchase our goods.
If the Commission genuinely believes that trade can promote development, then it should not block it.
The Committee on Development of this House has recommended rejecting the Commission's proposal.
And we should join that in plenary session.
Thank you. Both in Central America and in Peru and Colombia, there are an immense number of problems in the area of human rights.
And we, as Members of the European Parliament, cannot simply turn a blind eye to it.
We will thoroughly examine the roadmap for human rights demanded by the EP in the cases of Colombia and Peru, should it be drawn up.
It must possess substance and be binding, and include initial results such as the conviction of criminals and the safe return of displaced persons to their land.
And naturally, it must also be available before the vote on the agreement.

We Greens believe it is right that the Committee on International Trade is demanding environmental and social standards in the draft regulation on safeguard clauses, and not just tonnage restrictions for bananas.
The trilogue, however, must also confirm this, otherwise the regulation is worthless.
Indeed, the EU must do much more to consider the on-site situation and, above all, the impact on the local population.
And that is why we Greens are also demanding a proper impact assessment prior to each negotiation, one that examines not only the economic effects on the EU but also the effects on human rights.
Yes, thank you. Mr. Barroso, I made it clear already in the first round what I would like to emphasize.
My concern relates to the expectation of my group from the Commission that it fulfills its responsibility in the relevant bodies, such as the Troika, to clearly and distinctly state that we as
as European institutions stand accountable for ensuring that people are not driven further into poverty, that working hours are not reduced, that ecological social standards are not undermined.
That is their task.

And if we succeed in making that clear, then we also send a signal to the people who, in their thousands, hundreds of thousands, are protesting these days, who have taken to the streets, and with whom we, as a faction, also declare solidarity, whether in Thessaloniki or Barcelona.
I heard this morning that cancer patients in Greece are protesting and striking.
Where have we come to, that people facing deep social and personal hardship can no longer receive any assistance or support because the healthcare system has collapsed?
Here, we must finally become active.
And I would add one more thing: an approach that many decision-makers hold is that the people in Greece and in other countries have lived beyond their means.
You must be penalized today and must endure sanctions.
is unfit to strengthen a European community, a community based on solidarity.
I am not accusing you of this, Mr. Barroso, but this is an approach that permeates many countries and, unfortunately, repeatedly features in my own approach as well.
Mr. Chairman, I confess, I was mistaken.
I do not wish to make a statement regarding this report, but rather to address the report by Morera concerning the Agreement on Immediate Autonomous Trade Preferences for Pakistan.
I would like to be called back again.

Thank you, Madam President. The new directive establishes a framework for dealing with books, newspapers, artworks, films, musical pieces, and television productions that are, while protected by copyright, have an unidentified or unlocatable rights holder.
Accordingly, books, films, photos, or other intellectual creations for which no rightful owner can be found should also be made available to the public.
And so a cultural treasure is unearthed.
For us in the Culture Committee, it was of particular importance in this legislative initiative to emphasize the special significance of the diversity of the European Union’s cultural heritage.

In the archives of our museums, libraries, publishers, and broadcasting corporations, there exist countless unused works, and solely because their rightful owner is not known, they have not yet been made available.
That changes with the directive,
It will enable the future use of this cultural heritage asset, provided that a careful search is conducted prior to publication.
This is a very important point so that it is not said lightly, we cannot find the rightful owner.

For it was necessary to find a balance between the real existing rights of the creators of works and the need of the public, too, to be able to use such works where the legal situation cannot be clarified.
A particular focus for us has also been ensuring that both known and unknown rights holders continue to be fully protected.
And where the rights holders cannot be located, the draft facilitates the digitization of orphaned works.
Projects like Europäana and other large European digitization projects, as well as our museums, archives, educational institutions, and public broadcasting, will be sorted.
In the future, however, it must also concern itself with opening up the orphaned works in the archives of private publishers and the public domain.
This draft guideline and the compromise now found, in my view, truly represent a compromise and a first step in the right direction.
And I believe that the cultural treasure belonging to Hing holds enormous potential.
We should continue to work on this during the revision of the guideline in two years as well. Thank you very much.
Thank you, Mr. Chairman, esteemed Commissioner, Mr. President of the Council. I would be pleased if we could also include clear
Signals from the Council would show us how we can develop growth and competitiveness potential in Europe and, above all, how we could offer young people employment again.
Could you please inform us in which budget lines you intend to promote youth employment and prioritize entrepreneurship and small and medium-sized enterprises here?
We know that the ZIP program is the essential prerequisite for that. I only see cuts here from the council.
or the Erasmus for Young Entrepreneurs Programme or the Programme for Media Pluralism. Here, there are only cuts.
Do you believe that we can overcome the crisis in Europe by implementing cuts in areas that guarantee growth and employment?
I have heard that a growth and employment package is to be proposed by the Council.
Where is this to be found within the household as presented by the council?
Nordsee-Werken-Emmen was compelled to file for insolvency last Wednesday because a guarantee from the Lower Saxony state government was unexpectedly not extended.
This company, with 700 skilled positions, is undergoing a transformation from a shipyard to a supplier for offshore wind energy.

And now the idea is that this company can be rescued through a mass credit and that the jobs can also be saved. Because the 700 colleagues at SIAC and Nordseewerken have already had to accept significant reductions in their wages.

Therefore, I ask the Commission to examine this procedure favorably, but also promptly, so that these 700 jobs are not put at risk, because these 700 jobs are needed to organize the energy transition and to organize sustainable energy on the seas of Europe.
Please do not let the colleagues suffer as a result of the state government’s inadequate crisis management.
Milieu goods often appear innocuous, but in the hands of authoritarian regimes, they can be as dangerous as machine guns or tanks.
We undermine our foreign policy goals when we send surveillance technologies to authoritarian regimes that can use them to control and suppress democratic movements.
It was European mobile software from Nokia Siemens Network that played into the hands of Iranian security forces in suppressing the Green Movement protests.
Protesters were massively rounded up, arrested, tortured, and sentenced to death.
And that is just one example among many.
Furthermore, the Commission is also said to be promoting these questionable dual-use goods through the catalogue of measures for an innovative and competitive security sector.
The aim is to establish improved utilization of synergies between security and defense technologies.
We risk, for the sake of a questionable industrial policy, quite literally selling off human rights, as well as our own security interests.
Therefore, I would like to ask you to approve the proposed amendments from us, the Social Democrats, and all others.
Yes, I would like to ask colleague Regner, what do you believe unions could do, for example, to combat youth unemployment in Spain and Portugal?
Demonstrations will be insufficient.
What active role could the internal market play here?
Many thanks, Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues. I believe that with today’s debate on MiFID we are entering the core area of financial market regulation.
This legislative period has seen efforts to regulate financial markets, rather than merely examining individual products, as we have done in the past.
I would like to mention only a few key terms.
We certainly didn't make each other’s work very easy last year.

We conducted a hearing in committee, questioned all stakeholders, all interested parties, and, on that basis, developed a result—through various processes, working documents, and the like—which we will present to the plenary session for a vote today and tomorrow.
I would like to highlight a few key points.
Topic number one, market structure.

We must, of course, acknowledge on the one hand that significant changes have occurred in recent years within the financial markets. This is of interest to us, but as Parliament, our concern is that every trade of financial instruments that takes place occurs within the MiFID regulatory framework. Consequently, we are also examining, under many conditions, a new category,

have agreed to the so-called Organized Trading Facilities, where only non-equities are to be traded, where proprietary trading is to be prohibited, and where, in terms of execution concerning execution and transaction and client interaction, appropriate execution at their own discretion may occur.
I believe that we are making an important contribution to ensuring that the entire area of over-the-counter (OTC) papers that are traded is handled within the MiFID framework.
Another significant topic that was not yet considered in the previous MiFID is so-called algorithmic trading or high-frequency trading.

Here too, our aim was to establish clear rules of engagement, ensuring that this area, which can be very dangerous and can also be used manipulatively, is subject to strict regulations with minimum holding periods.

Disruption possibilities for trading, with the opportunity to test algorithms, with the possibility of supervisory structures examining algorithms, with the introduction of a so-called tick size regime, a minimum price increment, and through appropriate fee systems.
Another topic I would like to address is the area of commodity futures markets.

I do believe that we have a particular responsibility here when it comes to restricting the speculative element in genuine futures markets so that we do not contribute, through flawed regulations, to a situation in which people in the third and fourth worlds can no longer afford food.
We have therefore chosen a two-pronged approach, with the aim of curbing speculation while avoiding harm to the real economy.
With position limits, with strict upper limits for the number of contracts or positions, we aim to achieve this.

However, we also want to ensure, for those who can demonstrate a genuine need for a product, that they do not suddenly engage in speculative activity within this market as well, through a so-called position check system.
Another topic that occupies us considerably is the area of investor protection.
I would merely like to point out here that we have chosen a very broad approach when it comes to ensuring consumer protection and investor protection.
The objective here is to identify the needs of specific customer segments.
Not every small saver needs access to all highly complex financial instruments.

It concerns defining appropriate products for target groups, conducting product reviews, telephone recordings, relevant consultations, and disclosure obligations. But, and I also want to briefly indicate this, to apply subsidiarity in the area of commissions.
Member States shall, in accordance with their structures, have the possibility of making corresponding adjustments.
I believe that is the correct area.
Once my time expires, I wish to thank all those who have contributed here.
I find it regrettable that only four minutes of speaking time are allotted for such a complex dossier.
I would like to thank all colleagues who have contributed here, and the commission for its very constructive role in recent weeks and months.

And I hope that, with a strong vote from the plenary tomorrow, we will be in a position to enter negotiations with the Council in order to conclude this important dossier as soon as possible. Thank you.
Dear colleagues, thank you first of all for the overall good collaboration on this report.
We have been able to further improve a Commission proposal, which had already taken significant steps in the right direction, at central points.
Within the realm of market structures, there will be greater transparency, indeed, more comprehensive transparency, particularly in the area of derivatives trading.

under the framework of MiFID. The decisions in the area of high-frequency trading, our compromise, go far beyond what the Commission originally proposed and deserve the support of the Parliament as a whole.
And even regarding the topics that have provoked considerable public criticism, the report points in the right direction.

In the area of commodity and food speculation, following extensive and difficult debates—it must be said—it is now considerably stronger than the Commission’s resolutions, because position limits are now legally binding there.
We still need further changes in this area, however, to close any remaining gaps.
And I also hope for supplementary input here through the plenary vote and ultimately also then in the trilogue.
And it is gratifying that Mr. Barnier has already signaled his support for the Parliament’s more far-reaching proposal.
However, the report exhibits weaknesses in the area of consumer protection.
We now have the possibility to prohibit products, which is a step forward, but we still have no changes in the area of commission-driven advice.
The distribution of financial products remains oriented not primarily to the interests of customers, but is heavily dominated by which product yields the highest commission.
Even in Germany, but throughout the EU, consumers have lost a great deal of money.
Think of the open-ended real estate funds.
For citizens in countries such as France, Italy, Spain, and Germany, unfortunately, not much will change even after our compromise.
The fundamental principle will continue to be commission-based orientation.
To invoke subsidiarity here is somewhat simplistic.
Here, I would have wished for stricter regulations.
Madam President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, yes, what takes a long time, eventually turns out well, I can only say.
The report on type approval for L-category vehicles has, ultimately, turned out to be a good report after all.
The work took longer overall than we all thought and, above all, than we had hoped. And there were far more pitfalls than we ultimately would have liked.
But at this point, I would like to express my sincere thanks once again to the rapporteur, Mr. Vandekamp, for the truly cooperative and excellent collaboration.
Together, we were nevertheless able to achieve a great deal in the negotiations with the member states.
As rapporteur for my group, I recommend approving this report. Nevertheless, it could have been much better.
And with better, my esteemed colleagues, I mean safer.
For us Social Democrats, vehicle safety and thus the safety of drivers have been paramount from the outset. Particularly the safety of scooter riders and drivers, and motorcycle riders and drivers.
The number of motorcyclists involved in accidents, however, has remained constant for years.
In this case, the figures for fatalities in accidents generally decrease across Europe. Only in the case of motorcycle accidents does this not occur.
Reducing the number of motorcyclists and scooter riders killed is indeed a matter very close to my heart.
Fewer deaths on European roads – that was and remains my goal.
Every deceased person is one too many.
Especially in a regulation so advantageous for the internal market, this topic must be addressed intensively.
That this can be achieved through effective technologies such as anti-lock braking systems, or ABS, I remain convinced.
And I am equally convinced of its cost-effectiveness.
It is simply not true that ABS is too expensive.

We did, however, succeed in ensuring that, from 2016, all new and, from 2017, all existing motorcycle types with an engine displacement of 125cc or greater must be equipped with ABS by the manufacturer.
On scooters, manufacturers can optionally equip them with ABS or combined braking systems.
At this point, we must unfortunately concede that we have not achieved any improvements to the Commission's proposal.
I would have wished for considerably more here. But the Commission and Member States have, to put it cautiously, shown themselves to be very cumbersome.
Nevertheless, we succeeded in ensuring that the Commission presented a report in 2019.
The report must be fed with traffic accident data from the member states and should examine the mandatory installation of ABS on motor scooters.
Furthermore, it will be sent to the Parliament and the Council.
Based on this report, the Commission will then consider making the installation of ABS in scooters mandatory.
You see, the topic remains very, very alive.
Therefore, we will attempt to close the binding legislative gap starting in 2019.
I am confident that the collected data will substantiate my findings.
I am convinced that this is indeed a good day for riders of two-wheeled vehicles in Europe and that accident numbers will decrease in the future. Thank you.
Thank you, Mr. President. Matthias Grote, there is no technology without risks. There is no perfect energy generation technology.
and I believe that also applies to what we are discussing here today.
I am very much in favor of discussing this rationally.
What we are currently experiencing is a new addition to the energy markets through unconventional resources, specifically in the case of gas—primarily gas—but also in the case of oil and

I believe it is neither appropriate to succumb to excessive euphoria regarding a grand future for gas, nor is it appropriate, as some of my colleagues from the Greens and Left Party have done here, to paint apocalyptic scenarios that have nothing to do with reality.

I believe we must keep in mind that these unconventional resources have the potential to transform all existing energy supply relationships between providers and consumers, and that the economic viability calculations of previous energy sources are also being called into question.
We must confront this development.

I believe we should acknowledge that this can also be an opportunity for Europe, and not just a risk. We should prepare ourselves to view and utilize new technologies positively, to fairly weigh opportunities and risks, and to avoid falling into ideological debates. Thank you.
Mr. Commissioner, thank you for your response. It does not entirely satisfy me.
for I consider it a very, very long timeframe, a year between the notification that the complaint has been received and potentially receiving a response so late.
I believe that a complainant, who has taken the trouble – and usually has already exhausted all legal avenues in their member state – deserves more.
We rely on citizens to engage with the European Union.
If they do it in this way, we should treat them accordingly.

And I believe it is necessary and indispensable in the long term that we have here a procedure that is clearly formalized and that regulates rights clearly. This is now a declaration of how the Commission intends to handle this.
On another point. I have nothing against it, if it serves the purpose, that one attempts to achieve a kind of amicable clarification with the Member State together.
However, that will not always be sufficient.
We observe that, for example, in economic matters, things tend to move relatively quickly when one company sues another for a violation of EU law.

But when it comes, for example, to environmental issues and similar questions where a very, very large number of citizens demand the activity of the European Union or also social rights, then that process proceeds somewhat more arduously.
I believe that these facts, too, must be distinctly considered.
And I would like to see, for the next report, a clear formalization of the complainant’s rights vis-à-vis the Commission, one that is truly explicit and effectively communicated.
Once again, if we truly want European law to be applied after we have it processed here in the European Parliament, in the Council,
we have decided jointly. Then we must inform those who are responsible for this, those who are, so to speak, genuinely committed to European affairs, as thoroughly and precisely as possible.
This is a matter of great, great concern to me.
And I will also carefully observe what has developed here next time. Thank you.
Mr. President, colleagues, five years ago the European Union's Central Asia Strategy was launched.
If one inquires today about the assessment of this strategy, the evaluation proves to be ambivalent.

We observe how individual Member States strive for good economic relations, particularly with the resource-rich countries of this region. On the other hand, progress in these efforts is not forthcoming.
to accompany states in their transformation process toward modern democratic societies, or as recent events in Kazakhstan demonstrate, the development can even be characterized by setbacks.

Nevertheless, or indeed because of this, the European Union and the Member States must express their influence in this region more strongly together, including and especially towards Kazakhstan, which has now become a key supplier for several EU countries.

An isolation of Kazakhstan by the EU would only serve to allow competitors for influence in this geopolitically important country, to whom pressing for adherence to civil and human rights is of less concern, to assert their influence even more strongly than previously.
The linking of economic interests with the advocacy of safeguarding citizens’ rights is the core of the Central Asia strategy.
This should also form the basis for the subsequent negotiations regarding a partnership and cooperation agreement with Kazakhstan.

The present report provides good orientation on this matter.
Thank you very much.
Ladies and gentlemen of the absent council, perhaps you are following us via the Parliament's videostream, as you clearly lack neither the capacity nor the inclination to speak with us live.
I regard the Council's absence here and today as a gross disregard for Parliament.
Rather than avoiding this debate, you should instead reveal your reason for rejecting any improvement of the protection of personal data in the area of police and justice through a directive.

Police and justice authorities have, as we know, been an Eldorado of data protection violations for years. Not only in the case of SWIFT, but for example on a daily basis, by unlawfully collecting and storing data from citizens who, for example, demonstrate against Nazis.
We require equal protection standards for the public and private sectors, and for police and justice authorities. This is about being able to guarantee fundamental rights.
If you, the Council, request that the Parliament constructively participate in data protection-relevant regulations such as EU-PNA or Europol, then that must, conversely, also apply to the Council.
Therefore, I demand that you finally end the policy of obstruction in the area of data protection.
